> the UP!date 01 07 08
> (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)=20
> (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)=20
> (\o/)(\o/)
>
>
> contents
> Confessions of a Love & Cooperation Dissident
> Raver Madness!
> UP!date
>
>
> \)))))(/
> ____,,,,_{=F4=BF=F4}_,,,,_fraser
> it's the 40th anniversary of 1968 and all that, and everyone of a =20
> certain age seems to be writing about it.
> prospect magazine has hundreds here:
> http://www.prospect-magazine.co.uk/printarticle.php?id=3D10164
>
> so it seemed time to republish Confessions. i wrote this in the mid =20=

> '80s, and have only seen reasons to believe it more strongly from =20
> then till today:
> .
>
> Confessions of a
>
> Love & Cooperation Dissident
>
>
> After the collapse of Communism,
>
> the alternative overground model,
>
> An Attempt to Redefine & Re-present
>
> the Alternative Underground Model
>
>
>
>
>
> In Which It Is Asked
>
> With the Western Competitive Culture seemingly triumphant over =20
> Communism,
>
> has COOPERATION now become a dirty word like Socialism ...
>
> or is it re-emerging as an evolutionary virus
>
> which must dominate our global cultural body by the year 2000?
>
> Is it already, in fact, swarming in such abundance in every artery
>
> that the Alternative Underground Model is rapidly colonising the =20
> common mind as the new Religion?
>
>
>
> a forever-growing & finally unstoppable minority
> Ever since becoming an adult I've known in my bones, & softer =20
> places, that the Competitive Culture I'd been born into was on a =20
> dangerously deluded path which could only end in disaster.
>
> For everyone, the People and the privilegentsia!
>
> And all my adult life the elders & authorities of that System have =20
> retorted, first my mother, then teachers & churchmen, then every =20
> public or private executive I've encountered and, more recently as =20
> I've begun to raise my voice in public, the media:
>
> "You can't possibly believe that all the fully qualified =20
> professionals and experts, so obscenely well remunerated by our so =20
> wonderful, latest & greatest Super Power can have been hopelessly =20
> wrong all this time, and an isolated & not even"successful" =20
> individual such as you knew better all the time?!
>
> "Such arrogance approaches insanity!"
>
> Yet, mark well, the other "Super Power" turns out to have been in =20
> exactly such a state of affairs! My Russian dissident counterparts =20
> of the last 25 years were actually the only sane ones around!
>
> And those hundreds of thousands of power-dressed, bedside-mannered =20
> busynessmen, bureaucrats and executives really were purveyors and =20
> self-deluded victims of a sick consensus view of Reality. It now =20
> appears very possible indeed for an entire Society to be led in a =20
> completely unhealthy direction, and for a tiny but forevergrowing =20
> minority to be dissident and right.
>
>
>
> mirror images of the beast
>
> Despite the official Alternative Overground Model having collapsed =20
> and everything having changed, we're like the jumping bugs placed in =20=

> a bath with a sheet of glass laid over the top. After a day of =20
> continuously crashing back down, unconscious, the glass could be =20
> removed and virtually none of the bugs would jump out.
>
> THE BARRIERS HAVE BEEN REMOVED, BUT THE MAJORITY HAVE NOT YET =20
> NOTICED THE CHANGE, THE WINDOW THAT HAS OPENED!
>
> We've never, until now, been able to properly contemplate how =20
> ghastly, unhealthy, divisive and wasteful our competition-based =20
> system actually was because it was/is always compared to the =20
> Overground Alternative. Yet the brute fact is that the mere half =20
> century deep Soviet rebellion into Cooperation was actually the =20
> first mass uprising against our own Competitive culture, and the =20
> beginning of the final over-throw of the Competitive Party that's =20
> ruled for generations.
>
> The "odd" bug did jump out and escape. And now, as the bath water =20
> approaches boiling point, so many will start "jumping out" that soon =20=

> they'll be taking over the Reality Studio itself.
>
> And, just as most Russian dissidents were not advocating Capitalism =20=

> as the alternative, so the vast majority of Cooperation dissidents =20
> in the West, certainly since the 60s when I became an adult, were =20
> never ever advocating State Communism.
>
> Indeed I joined the Hippies out of a deep, clear conviction that =20
> both Communism and Capitalism were user-unfriendly, for all their =20
> citizens. I saw the "Hippy" then, as I do today, tweaked into a =20
> Zippy, as the true Alternative lifestyle and worldview to the =20
> present sick consensus reality.
>
> More, as the '70s wore on and the Hippy Renaissance was turned back =20=

> on most fronts, I became convinced we were already living in the =20
> material wilderness of psychopathic alienation to which such a =20
> competitive culture must lead - poisoned air, water, food, and =20
> private-public relationships. Even then I sensed we'd look back on =20
> the millennium's end as the Culmination & Final Death Throes of the =20=

> Dark Ages.
>
> The '80s, of course, were a further, probably fatal acceleration =20
> down this inevitable consequence. Both systems turn out to have been =20=

> mirror images of the Beast of whom the prophets warned.
>
> One down, one well on its way, that's my attitude now!
> Fraser Clark. London. 1989.
> UP!date
>
> (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/) (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)=20
> (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)
> TEXT JOCKEY //TJ PHRASER (Fraser Clark) & THE MEDIA EVOLUTION
> MIXING THE TRACTS LIVE ON THE KEYBOARD
> @ A MEDIA-MEME RATE OF 160 IPP * * Ideas Per Paragraph
> (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)=20
> (\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)(\o/)
>
> Raver Madness!
> One Man's Story of the
> Zippy Pronoia Tour To US :)
> POSSIBLY THE MOST COSMIC DOCUMENT U WILL EVER READ :)
> http://www.scribd.com/doc/2414770/Raver-Madness-12
> UP!date
>
> all g o o d t h i n g s c o m e t o a n e n d
> which don't justify nuttin'

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is =20
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids =20
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Saturday, July 5th, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 1st Saturday at The Endup


featuring from Stockholm via Los Angeles:

MIKAEL STAV=D6STRAND   ** LIVE PA **

Sunset Diskos . We Are . Adjunct . Kindisch . Force Inc
Get Physical . Spectral . Mo's Ferry . Contexterrior

The madness rages on as [KONTROL] completes our three
month Swedish trifecta with Stockholm label owner, producer,
and exhilarating live performer Mikael Stav=F6strand.  His long
and highly respected career has seen thirty 12" and nineteen
full album releases on many of the world's top labels, ranging
from his early experimental and industrial works to the deep,
dark, and funky dancefloor grooves he's known for today.
Often cited as a standout of last year's Decibel Festival, don't
miss his much anticipated SF debut!


and from St. Louis via Berlin:

BUTANE

Alphahouse . Dumb-Unit . Rrygular . Num . Siteholder
Esperanza . Mo's Ferry . Foundsound . Freak n' Chic

Andrew Rasse helped put St. Louis on the global techno map
with his successful Alphahouse label and infamous parties of
the same name before defecting to Berlin a few years ago.
As a producer, his tracks have been a staple of the top jocks
on the planet, but anyone who's heard him spin will tell you
that it's his dynamic and seamless DJ sets you don't want to
miss.  Expect everything from warm, cerebral house to face-
melting peak hour techno from one of the State's finest exports.


with [KONTROL] residents:

CRAIG KUNA   ( platform . esdjco )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( nightlight . auralism . leibe*detail )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 8am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________

Full bios, pics and lots FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K37/K37F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K37/K37B.jpg

Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K37/K37P.jpg

____________________________________________________


MIKAEL STAV=D6STRAND  (aka The Skull, Bulgur Brothers, Vita)

Mikael Stav=F6strand was born in Stockholm, Sweden 1972, and is now
based in Berlin, Germany.  He has been lauded as a key figure of the
Swedish electronic music scene for his unique interpretations of
minimal club techno as well as for producing some of the most
essential experimental electronic music of the past years. Stav=F6strand
mixes deconstructed sounds with funky little beats to create minimal
dance textures. On his debut album on Force Inc., "Reduce", swarms of
glitches, crackles and skips infiltrate the 4/4 drive formula of
minimal techno. As Vita, his "Vita" 12" on Force Inc. imprint Force
Labs was welcomed by critical praise and became one of the best
selling releases with its digitalized organic groove.

He started to produce music in the early nineties, but back then he
was a part of the industrial scene and released some now labeled as
"classic" records under different names. Lately due to a lot of demand
from different labels, he agreed to allow reissues of these early
works.  After that period he got more interested into sound research
and minimalism, which also led to a couple of CD releases on labels as
Staalplaat in The Netherlands to name a few. In 2000 he became more
focused on bringing his experiences and sound from the pure minimal
scene into a more club context, so he started to work with minimal
techno sounds, which immediately resulted in releases on Force Inc. in
Germany. He has released 30 12" Ep's and 19 Albums (CD, DLP, LP) so
far and he has been featured on many compilation records. He is also a
sought after as a remix artist.

In recent years he has been playing live around the world at such
events as Mutek in Canada and in Mexico and Swedish Style in Tokyo. He
has also played in Japan and all over Europe at respected clubs such
as Panorama Bar, Weekend, Watergate, Fuse, Otto Zuts, Cargo,
Brancaleone and many more. He is often asked by Swedish Cultural
Institutes to represent Sweden abroad at festivals (ex. Detali Zvuku
in Kiev, Take me to Sweden in Berlin and Swedish Style in Tokyo).

Between 2000 to 2007 he ran the record label Mitek. Mitek's aim was to
produce and promote upcoming Swedish talents in the field of
electronic music. In the years Mitek produced 22 records with
different kinds of electronic music, from avant-garde to club. Mitek
often received grants from The Swedish Art Council to produce the
records.  In the summer of 2006 he also started his new label "Sunset
Diskos". This label is purely for club music and deep, funky minimal
tunes are the aim here. With artists such as himself, [a]pendics
shuffle, agaric & Bulgur Brothers, Pheek and Franco Cinelli.  Now he
is signed by Get Physical [DE], Spectral Sound [US], We Are [SE],
Sushitech [UK], Thema [US] and others, with more exciting prospects on
the way soon.

Recently he licensed tracks for Audion's Fabric mix CD, a new mix CD
by James Holden, Circo Loco @ DC10 CD in Mixmag March issue and Fuse
presents Steve Bug mix CD plus upcoming mix CD's by Agoria, Steve Bug
and MANDY. His music is heavily played by DJ's as Matthew Dear, MANDY,
Ricardo Villalobos, DJ T, Ryan Elliot, Jeff Samuel, Tanya Vulcano,
Marco Carola, Dinky, Butane, Jeff Milligan, Troy Pierce, Magda and Jay
Haze to name a few.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

Mikael Stav=F6strand's website:
http://www.sunset-diskos.com/

Mikael Stav=F6strand's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Mikael+Stav%C3%B6strand

Mikael Stav=F6strand on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/mikaelstavostrand

Mikael Stav=F6strand @ Tresor, Berlin  01.12.08
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DwfdX6pIABn8


____________________________________________________


BUTANE

Label owner of Alphahouse Records, accomplished producer, and jet
setting DJ, Butane (Andrew Rasse) hails from the Midwestern United
States, the birthplace of many great electronic music acts. His
infamous Alphahouse monthly party put St. Louis on the current
worldwide techno map, and his record label is regarded as one of the
premier minimal techno/house labels in North America.

As a DJ, Andrew uses vinyl, Traktor Scratch, samplers, effects, and
whatever other new tools are available to craft his sets. Plenty of
experience in clubs enables him to move bodies while simultaneously
keeping a distinctly heady vibe. Technically gifted, with an ear for
deepness, and not afraid to take the crowd where they need to go, he
prides himself on playing appropriately for any time or setting.
Because of this musical range, expect anything from seamlessly blended
groovy, sexy, peak-time techno to warm, deep, cerebral house music.

As a music producer, his tracks have been featured on some of the
world's most forward-thinking underground labels.  Licensing original
tracks to mix compilations such as Matthew Dear's Fabric mix,
Luciano's HiFi SciFi on Soma, and Damian Lazarus' Get Lost mix, it's
obvious that his peers in the industry hold his music in high regard.

Always one to rely on his talents for success rather than shameless
promotional methods, Andrew remains increasingly busy on the
international DJ circuit. His touring schedule in the past year has
included gigs in Paris, Berlin, Amsterdam, Tokyo, Cape Town, Moscow,
Mexico City, London, Melbourne, Sydney, Budapest, Rome, Barcelona,
Detroit, New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago, among many others. Rave
reviews of his sets continue to pour in from underground outposts
around the globe.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

Butane's website:
http://www.alphahousemusic.com/

Butane on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/butane_alphahouse

Butane's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Butane

Recent interview for MUTEKMAG:
http://www.mutek.org/magazine/index.php/post/3/

I don't mind paying an extra $5 per bag of weed if it means I can smoke it
wherever I want without fear and not have to put my name on a
government-owned list.  And above that, I'm willing to pay a little extra
money to get high if it means progress towards legality on the federal
level, which this might eventually prompt.  I'd just really like to know
what they're proposing to do with all this new revenue.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Can't beleive no one has commented on the BM trial outcome...

So what impact will this have on the event?    

I increasingly see the people that make the art being disillusioned with Burning Man for various reasons.  Many people I know (and they are the ones making some of the best art on the playa) don't go anymore.  Some actively bitch about the old days etc., but most simply don't bother to go and aren't interested in the politics.  I have to imagine that the quality of the art has and will continue to suffer as these individuals are replaced by RVs full of frat boys and their faux burner barbie girlfriends.  

I'm saddened by the sentencing of Mr. Addis, who seems like he is
troubled and for some reason is willing to make a martyr of himself (pleading guilty) to prove the point
about what BM has become.  I think he's made a huge mistake here, as
uncovering the falsehood of the myth associated with Burning Man simply wasn't
ever worth ruining his life over.  But now its too late for that.  He's fucked royally. 

As an outsider maybe my opinion doesn't matter much.  I've never been to BM, but over the years my interest in going to the event has waned.  And after hearing about these events I doubt that I'll ever go.  This story just confirms what I've thought for a while now, that Burning Man as a counter culture symbol has been totally commodified and absorbed into the mainstream consumerist American culture.  

That doesn't mean that Burning Man isn't a fun music and art festival like Coachella or Glastonbury or whatever, but that's all it is.   I'm just as unmotivated to go to Coachella as Burning Man.  The supposed community and counter culture principles of the event have now been shown clearly to be merely marketing hype and brand/lifestyle indicators intended to promote the business that is Burning Man LLC.  And like many other business, the LLC  decide to minimize the financial impact of these events on the business and to ensure that the business was not harmed in the future.  I don't see an evidence of considering the impact on the community or their so called principles.  Totally expected for a business, but not for a radical counter culture social revolution.

I ask therefore, will 2008 be the last Burning Man?  And will Addis' actions be the trigger that ended it?  

After reading Chicken John's and other's postings over on Laughing Squid, I have to wonder if the LLC isn't giving Mr. Addis exactly what he wanted by allowing his prosecution: the death of the LLC in an implosion of hypocrisy and greed.

Peace,

Peter

PS I predict ClearChannel will make an offer to buy out the BM LLC in 2009. Stay Tuned.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] No more prescriptions, but a state tax...I'm in!

For me this is about California recognizing bud for more than just medical
reasons. Recreational use opens a huge range of possible lifestyle changes
for residents:

-Smoking in public (without fear)
-Cafes and Chef Spealities
-Drive Throughs (can only image visitors from other states)
-Home gardening and cultivation
-More THC Edibles
-Availablity in Night Life Bars/Clubs
-Stress Balancing with the over-worked, more pysch studies
-Open discussions with Family members and public forums

These are the only ones I can imagine, I'm sure it will grow beyond that. I
would hope that local law enforcement would be able to tell when one is high
while driving or other heavey machine operating (Humboldt has a swab test to
detect usage upto 12hrs ago).

Sure its been legal The Netherlands for a while, but combine legality with
capalist society...itll get crazy.

-Smith

I don't mind paying an extra $5 per bag of weed if it means I can smoke it
wherever I want without fear and not have to put my name on a
government-owned list.  And above that, I'm willing to pay a little extra
money to get high if it means progress towards legality on the federal
level, which this might eventually prompt.  I'd just really like to know
what they're proposing to do with all this new revenue.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Can't beleive no one has commented on the   BM trial outcome...

IMO I don't need to have been there to see the injustice of sending a
mentally disturbed person to jail for years for what is really just an act of vandalism. 

As I wrote earlier
today, I think BM LLC is giving Addis exactly what he wanted which seems to be
the martyr and bring the LLC down with him.  And through arrogance,
greed, or maybe just stupidity, they are playing the role of the selfish evil empire he set up for
them to play.  That's a very unfortunate choice IMO.  This decision might very well spell the end of the event.  Or maybe not.

Your description doesn't seem me to be in conflict with the multiple and varied sources I've read today which state no one was endangered.  It seems to be a matter of personal interpretation about how much danger there really was.  Since no more serious charges were filed (i.e. attempted manslaughter) I'm going to go out on a limb and claim that the danger was in fact rather limited.

And just exactly what constitutes endangering someone at Burning Man?  Was the early burn any more dangerous than thousands of other things that have happened on the playa over the years?  I personally doubt that given some of things I have heard from friends that have been at many burns.  

Hypocrisy is the greatest luxury...

Regards, 

Peter

I don't really see what the big deal is.  I think it was pretty fuckin funny
that he burned the man early.  it was pretty good timing too with the full
moon lunar eclipse.  He lit it up at just the right time, it was rather
spectacular.  The monday night burn was much more amazing than the pussy job
that took at least a half hour on saturday the "official burn".

And about the people who were underneath the man

there's this disclaimer on the burning man ticket that goes

"YOU VOLUNTARILY ASSUME THE RISK OF SERIOUS INJURY OR DEATH BY ATTENDING AND
RELEASE BURNING MAN FROM ANY CLAIMS FROM THIS RISK" and continues in
detail.

basically, its not BRC's job to hold your fucking hand

you're in the desert

drink water

watch out for falling fire

and other dangers


I'm pretty suprised though, I would think BRC wouldn't have pressed
charges.  I don't see the big deal anyways

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i've spent 8 years at burning man, which is less than some but enough to gain a bit of perspective, and i agree completely with the statements below. count me amongst those who no longer feel any draw towards what has been reduced to just another big party.

let's be real here though - this isn't the first time burning man has endured a mass exodus and i'm sure it won't be the last. there are more than enough bros and fur bunnies and vegas cheesedicks to sustain the event financially for a long time to come. i doubt addis reached anyone who didn't already at least partially agree with his position, and i hardly think this signals the beginning of the end. this is just another weird art project whose memory will be lost in the comedown. if i believed burning man was actually creating anything lasting or meaningful in its current state, i'd still be in attendance.

love,
mo

most simply don't bother to go and aren't interested in the politics. 
 
This story just confirms what I've thought for a while now, 
that Burning Man as a counter culture symbol has been totally commodified 
and absorbed into the mainstream consumerist American culture.  

That doesn't mean that Burning Man isn't a fun music and art festival 
like Coachella or Glastonbury or whatever, but that's all it is. 


      
--0-338767542-1214962121=:25371--

Message-Id: <20080702025949.3C071BE8C3@green.rahul.net>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Burning Man

2007 was the worst BM I've seen - the art was not up to what it was 
in the past, the X shortage had everyone uptight, the relentless 
daily dust storms. So what? We'll be there again this year.

I kind of like all the middle class RVers, gearheads, hollywood 
doofuses, locals, and Indians coming to BM. Who the hell wants to 
hang out in a candyrave art-school ghetto? Gimme real people, thank 
you... (Well, yeah, fuck the frat-boys.)

Reports of BMs demise are premature. It is what it is. Eventually it 
will be killed, but it ain't dead yet. Last year we took people who 
had never been who claimed it was life-changing. I figure if the 
worst BM ever could do that, it will have a long way to fall before it dies.

If you refuse to go because it "just isn't cool enough anymore", it 
defaults to the assholes. It is still worth going to. It will have to 
suck a lot more than it does now to keep me away.

It's a party. Lighten up.


David Theodoropoulos/Sheri Calkins 


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How do i get just rave event info emails only?

--0-2046403729-1214968689=:85990
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

if you look at the subject line, you'll notice some text that says
"NRR". this means "not rave related" and it's in the subject line of
any topic that's about anything other than raves. if you set up your
filters to put all the NRR stuff in a different folder, you should be
left with just the ravetastic rave emails :)

love,
mo

*bliss does not require ignorance*

On 1 July 2008, David Theodoropoulos/Sheri Calkins wrote:

> It's a party. Lighten up.

It was when I started having friends, who I respected, have the first 
words they used to describe BM to those who haven't been be along the 
lines of "it's a great party" that I knew the event was I respected was 
on the decline.  For me, the party aspect was the icing on the cake. 
The cake itself has dried up a while ago, it seems.

Subject: Re: NRR: Re: [sfraves] Burning Man

Points well taken! After last year I said I was through going, but a 
little time healed that. You may well be right about the frat-boy 
faux fur alcohol disaster waiting to happen. I sure hope not, which 
is one reason I'll continue to go, probably too many times - I'll 
quit a year or two later than I should...

Didn't mean to imply that it is your "responsibility to maintain the 
quality of the BM event or audience either by attending or not 
attending the Burn." I just figure if we leave early we may just hurt 
ourselves. I really don't know. Again, point well taken, and you may 
be right. As Yogi Berra once said of some place or another "Nobody 
goes there anymore - it's too crowded."

I'm not really up on all the politics of the LLC and their profit or 
whether this is exploiting those of us who go to give freely. I've 
heard a fair amount about it, but don't really feel informed on the 
issues, so you may be right. I just figure I'm going to give and not 
expect anything in return, and that's just part of what it is about. 
Of course I'm not putting up some multi-thousand dollar art project, 
just sharing what I have.

Takers will always be out there, but I'm not going to let them take 
my humanity by sucking me into the balance sheet view of life. So I 
get exploited by a few takers - what else is new? At least I'll keep 
my humanity...

You may well be right about all of it. I hope not. Anyway, whatever 
you choose, I'll send my Respect! But I'll be sorry not to see you 
there, whoever you are - one fewer of us to make it happen.

If somebody throws a rave, and nobody shows up, is there any dancing?

Thank you all for all you do - thanks to everyone who comes together 
to make our thing happen, whenever and wherever. As long as we make 
love, get high, and dance, everythang's gonna be all right. That's 
all I care about... I'm no DJ or promoter or anything at all - I just 
wanna dance...

Best Wishes,

--David

David Theodoropoulos/Sheri Calkins

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

this might be an appropriate time to also mention the calendar and events
list over at blipswitch.com.

the site is geared mainly towards techno and other 4/4 bizness, but any
events are welcome.  i don't really have anything to do with the site, but i
did volunteer to moderate the events section.

its also a nice (if small) little community of techno fans, DJs, promoters
and such, and gets a decent (but not obnoxious) amount of posting action.
also some nice mixes posted for free download, chatter about gear, etc.

check it out and feel free to sign up and join in, it's growing by the day
and we're are hoping to make it a resource for all flavors of raveyness.

http://blipswitch.net/forum/


pz---->GB

> this might be an appropriate time to also mention the calendar and events
> list over at blipswitch.com.
>
> the site is geared mainly towards techno and other 4/4 bizness, but any
> events are welcome.  i don't really have anything to do with the site, but i
> did volunteer to moderate the events section.
>
> its also a nice (if small) little community of techno fans, DJs, promoters
> and such, and gets a decent (but not obnoxious) amount of posting action.
> also some nice mixes posted for free download, chatter about gear, etc.
>
> check it out and feel free to sign up and join in, it's growing by the day
> and we're are hoping to make it a resource for all flavors of raveyness.
>
> http://blipswitch.net/forum/

Only thing is that I think that the process of:
1. logging in to a forum
2. clicking on links to navigate a forum's messages
3. clicking on links to post to a forum
is SUCH a waste of time.  (Thus why I generally don't participate in web 
based forums.)  I don't have that time to waste.

Now if it becomes as efficient as utilizing an email list, count me in.

Looks like fine content however.  I don't even see an rss feed.  Sad I 
won't be taking part. :(

SFgoth fixed this problem a long time ago...

One list, two types of subs.

SFG-  Just like SFR

SFG-A  Announce only.  All posts made by SFG-A go to SFG by default, but 
not the other way.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How do i get just rave event info emails only?



Yep, I've seen many multiple level lists,

moderated/edited: The moderators periodically post a newsletter/blast with
summary info.  copies to:

news/announce: for announcements only, violations subject to bans, copies
to: 

discussion/anything goes.  These can even be 2 levels.

People sub at the level of noise they want and get everything above.

Can work, but if not done carefully, can lead to a lot of resentment over
people taking so much liberty with the "open" list at the end that they
end up driving everyone off and killing the topic-related discussion too.

-R.

you can do this with one list, that's what the subject tags are for.

all the announcements have BSP: in the subject line, so you could 
start out by filtering out everything that doesn't.

Message-ID: <da3fea7c0807021232i202a3badvc792bba7b4cbd521@mail.gmail.com>

From: "Chelsea Faith" <chelcfaith@gmail.com>
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; 
	boundary="----=_Part_1935_10252473.1215027133510"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR - A soon-disappearing resource for free music

------=_Part_1935_10252473.1215027133510
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I used to work for this company called Soundflavor, which was attempting to
creating a music search engine and music recommendation software that worked
with musical qualities that we music "experts" who worked there determined.
 Sort of like Pandora. I was their electronic music specialist. It was a
cool job, I had fun, but they laid me off when things started to slide
downhill.  Ahh startups....
Anyway, why I am telling you guys about Soundflavor now is this -  I just
found out from a former co-worker that the company is going belly-up for
good in about a month.  Soundflavor's website, soundflavor.com, is a huge
resource for free music, a lot of which is actually pretty good. Since the
company is dead, I assume that the website will be coming down really soon,
along with all the free tunes.  I highly recommend you check out the site
and grab some music while it's still there.

You can browse by genre, and while it's not perfect, most of the
classifications on the site should be halfway decent - I personally
classified a lot of the electronic stuff while I was working there.  As I
recall, there was a lot of good tech-house, a ton of progressive, some
minimal and dubby techno, I seem to remember a lot of acid breaks coming in
too.  On the main page, click on the button that says Free Songs, then from
there you can browse by genre and subgenre, tempo, year recorded,
instruments, or tell it a song that you like and it will find other tracks
it thinks sound similar.  It's worth checking out - www.soundflavor.com

Love Chelsea

------=_Part_1935_10252473.1215027133510--

follow through with their idea.

to implement it. Brian's idea was a wiki. Perhaps we could even 
do a blog, (takes care of the RSS).

Dunno, we have resources here. Just not anyone(s) to follow 
through with it.

hope in the world again.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fun at Supper Club tonight


Actually, I haven't seen much promo in general for this event, given how
many DJs I know are on the roster.  In terms of online, what I mean is that
I typically see a half dozen or more mentions of a given event over various
lists, plus various websites, and lots of myspace mentions of said events.
For this, I've seen mentions from David Javate, Alland and Amber.

It's one of those things; if we only ever promote to our friends, we end
up with some pretty small parties.  Admittedly, you probably have a lot
more friends than I do, but I'm pretty sure that with parties you throw,
for example, you reach out to a lot more people than just them.  Like that
one I think you're throwing this Saturday, I bet at least a few people you
and the other guys have never met know about it. ;-)  Sure, you and the
kontrol crew probably do a better job promoting than almost any other
party in the city, but there's a lot of room between how much I've seen
for the nextaid benefit and that.

Given that it's for a particular cause, I'm also rather surprised there
hasn't been more noise from other folks who believe in NextAid, also.

stuck at work instead of killswitch,
-R.

Saturday, July 5th, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 1st Saturday at The Endup


featuring from Stockholm via Los Angeles:

MIKAEL STAV=D6STRAND   ** LIVE PA **

Sunset Diskos . We Are . Adjunct . Kindisch . Force Inc
Get Physical . Spectral . Mo's Ferry . Contexterrior

The madness rages on as [KONTROL] completes our three
month Swedish trifecta with Stockholm label owner, producer,
and exhilarating live performer Mikael Stav=F6strand.  His long
and highly respected career has seen thirty 12" and nineteen
full album releases on many of the world's top labels, ranging
from his early experimental and industrial works to the deep,
dark, and funky dancefloor grooves he's known for today.
Often cited as a standout of last year's Decibel Festival, don't
miss his much anticipated SF debut!


and from St. Louis via Berlin:

BUTANE

Alphahouse . Dumb-Unit . Rrygular . Num . Siteholder
Esperanza . Mo's Ferry . Foundsound . Freak n' Chic

Andrew Rasse helped put St. Louis on the global techno map
with his successful Alphahouse label and infamous parties of
the same name before defecting to Berlin a few years ago.
As a producer, his tracks have been a staple of the top jocks
on the planet, but anyone who's heard him spin will tell you
that it's his dynamic and seamless DJ sets you don't want to
miss.  Expect everything from warm, cerebral house to face-
melting peak hour techno from one of the State's finest exports.


with [KONTROL] residents:

CRAIG KUNA   ( platform . esdjco )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( nightlight . auralism . leibe*detail )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( robsoul . junior boys own . s.w.a.t. )
SAMMY D   ( classic . dirtybird . utensil )

____________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

http://www.kontrolsf.com

____________________________________________________


MIKAEL STAV=D6STRAND  (aka The Skull, Bulgur Brothers, Vita)

Mikael Stav=F6strand was born in Stockholm, Sweden 1972, and is now based i=
n
Berlin, Germany.  He has been lauded as a key figure of the Swedish
electronic music scene for his unique interpretations of minimal club techn=
o
as well as for producing some of the most essential experimental electronic
music of the past years. Stav=F6strand mixes deconstructed sounds with funk=
y
little beats to create minimal dance textures. On his debut album on Force
Inc., "Reduce", swarms of glitches, crackles and skips infiltrate the 4/4
drive formula of minimal techno. As Vita, his "Vita" 12" on Force Inc.
imprint Force Labs was welcomed by critical praise and became one of the
best selling releases with its digitalized organic groove.

He started to produce music in the early nineties, but back then he was a
part of the industrial scene and released some now labeled as "classic"
records under different names. Lately due to a lot of demand from different
labels, he agreed to allow reissues of these early works.  After that perio=
d
he got more interested into sound research and minimalism, which also led t=
o
a couple of CD releases on labels as Staalplaat in The Netherlands to name =
a
few. In 2000 he became more focused on bringing his experiences and sound
from the pure minimal scene into a more club context, so he started to work
with minimal techno sounds, which immediately resulted in releases on Force
Inc. in Germany. He has released 30 12" Ep's and 19 Albums (CD, DLP, LP) so
far and he has been featured on many compilation records. He is also a
sought after as a remix artist.

In recent years he has been playing live around the world at such events as
Mutek in Canada and in Mexico and Swedish Style in Tokyo. He has also playe=
d
in Japan and all over Europe at respected clubs such as Panorama Bar,
Weekend, Watergate, Fuse, Otto Zuts, Cargo, Brancaleone and many more. He i=
s
often asked by Swedish Cultural Institutes to represent Sweden abroad at
festivals (ex. Detali Zvuku in Kiev, Take me to Sweden in Berlin and Swedis=
h
Style in Tokyo).

Between 2000 to 2007 he ran the record label Mitek. Mitek's aim was to
produce and promote upcoming Swedish talents in the field of electronic
music. In the years Mitek produced 22 records with different kinds of
electronic music, from avant-garde to club. Mitek often received grants fro=
m
The Swedish Art Council to produce the records.  In the summer of 2006 he
also started his new label "Sunset Diskos". This label is purely for club
music and deep, funky minimal tunes are the aim here. With artists such as
himself, [a]pendics shuffle, agaric & Bulgur Brothers, Pheek and Franco
Cinelli.  Now he is signed by Get Physical [DE], Spectral Sound [US], We Ar=
e
[SE], Sushitech [UK], Thema [US] and others, with more exciting prospects o=
n
the way soon.

Recently he licensed tracks for Audion's Fabric mix CD, a new mix CD by
James Holden, Circo Loco @ DC10 CD in Mixmag March issue and Fuse presents
Steve Bug mix CD plus upcoming mix CD's by Agoria, Steve Bug and MANDY. His
music is heavily played by DJ's as Matthew Dear, MANDY, Ricardo Villalobos,
DJ T, Ryan Elliot, Jeff Samuel, Tanya Vulcano, Marco Carola, Dinky, Butane,
Jeff Milligan, Troy Pierce, Magda and Jay Haze to name a few.

http://www.discogs.com/artist/Mikael+Stav%C3%B6strand

Mikael Stav=F6strand on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/mikaelstavostrand

____________________________________________________


BUTANE

Label owner of Alphahouse Records, accomplished producer, and jet setting
DJ, Butane (Andrew Rasse) hails from the Midwestern United States, the
birthplace of many great electronic music acts. His infamous Alphahouse
monthly party put St. Louis on the current worldwide techno map, and his
record label is regarded as one of the premier minimal techno/house labels
in North America.

As a DJ, Andrew uses vinyl, Traktor Scratch, samplers, effects, and whateve=
r
other new tools are available to craft his sets. Plenty of experience in
clubs enables him to move bodies while simultaneously keeping a distinctly
heady vibe. Technically gifted, with an ear for deepness, and not afraid to
take the crowd where they need to go, he prides himself on playing
appropriately for any time or setting. Because of this musical range, expec=
t
anything from seamlessly blended groovy, sexy, peak-time techno to warm,
deep, cerebral house music.

As a music producer, his tracks have been featured on some of the world's
most forward-thinking underground labels.  Licensing original tracks to mix
compilations such as Matthew Dear's Fabric mix, Luciano's HiFi SciFi on
Soma, and Damian Lazarus' Get Lost mix, it's obvious that his peers in the
industry hold his music in high regard.

Always one to rely on his talents for success rather than shameless
promotional methods, Andrew remains increasingly busy on the international
DJ circuit. His touring schedule in the past year has included gigs in
Paris, Berlin, Amsterdam, Tokyo, Cape Town, Moscow, Mexico City, London,
Melbourne, Sydney, Budapest, Rome, Barcelona, Detroit, New York, Los
Angeles, and Chicago, among many others. Rave reviews of his sets continue
to pour in from underground outposts around the globe.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

http://www.alphahousemusic.com/

Butane on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/butane_alphahouse

Butane's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Butane

Recent interview for MUTEKMAG:
http://www.mutek.org/magazine/index.php/post/3/

2007%20mix%5d.mp3

http://www.alphahousemusic.com/music/butane%20-%20engineered%20for%20sunday=
%20%5bdecember%202007%20mix%5d.mp3

Britain's erstwhile rave culture

In 1988, Thatcher=92s Britain was hit by an almighty day-glo wake-up =20
call: the birth of the acid-house party. Twenty years on, we remember =20=

the clothes, the drugs and the music =97 and asks how rave culture has =20=

shaped the way we live today
Kate Spicer

I was due on stage at 8am,=94 recalls the acid-house pioneer Trevor =20
Fung. =93It was a beautiful sunny morning. I=92d never seen so many =
people =20
in my life =97 there must have been 20,000 out there. There were three =20=

juggernauts in this huge field; two were piled with speakers. I got on =20=

the one in the middle with the decks on. I just walked on, waved, =20
dropped the needle on the record... and it all went off.=94

This was towards the end of the second summer of love, the name given =20=

to the period in 1988-89 when dance music, youth culture and a =20
generation=92s expectations of fun did, indeed, go off in a singular and =
=20
spectacular way. That summer of love was, for those who were there, a =20=

fortuitous collision of several cultural phenomena. There was the =20
little-known acid-house music coming out of Chicago. There was the =20
importing, by a group of young London DJs, of a very Ibizan way of =20
partying, with abandon and a total disregard for respecting the =20
boundaries around musical genres (and the little matter of the MDMA =20
they found there, which was a popular agent for their hedonism). With =20=

their passion for the music, they blew the existing free and illegal =20
warehouse party scene wide open, making it accessible to people more =20
used to the dire Hit Man and Her-style clubbing of Ritzy=92s, on the =20
high street. In the summer of love, Britain found fun =97 and found it =20=

on an epic scale.

CONTINUED:  =
http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/ar=
ticle4255627.ece


apollo@speakeasy.org

nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids =20
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of =20
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will =20
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"A human being is a part of the whole, called by us, "Universe," a  
part limited in time and space. He experiences himself, his thoughts  
and feelings as something separated from the rest -- a kind of optical  
delusion of his consciousness. This delusion is a kind of prison for  
us, restricting us to our personal desires and to affection for a few  
persons nearest to us. Our task must be to free ourselves from this  
prison by widening our circle of compassion to embrace all living  
creatures and the whole of nature in its beauty. Nobody is able to  
achieve this completely, but the striving for such achievement is in  
itself a part of the liberation and a foundation for inner  
security." : Albert Einstein - (1879-1955) Physicist and Professor,  
Nobel Prize 1921

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is  
nothing but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids  
look and look and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of  
the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will  
gradually become visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] RG: Last Wiretapping vote Tues 7/8 please call your senator (lowercase
 S these days) on Mon

(Please send this to others!)  This crosses political lines - the
Republicans wouldn't give Clinton increased wiretapping powers either.



http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/la-op-sanchez16mar16,0,4039194.story



"The original FISA law was passed in 1978 after a thorough congressional
investigation headed by Sen. Frank Church (D-Idaho) revealed that for
decades, intelligence analysts -- and the presidents they served -- had
spied on the letters and phone conversations of union chiefs, civil rights
leaders, journalists, antiwar activists, lobbyists, members of Congress,
Supreme Court justices -- even Eleanor Roosevelt and the Rev. Martin Luther
King Jr. The Church Committee (Watergate) reports painstakingly documented
how the information obtained was often "collected and disseminated in order
to serve the purely political interests of an intelligence agency or the
administration, and to influence social policy and political action."



Contact lookup:

https://secure.eff.org/site/Advocacy?alertId=389
<https://secure.eff.org/site/Advocacy?alertId=389&pg=makeACall>
&pg=makeACall





or, for you Californians, Diane Feinstein: Phone: (202) 224-3841 District 
Phone: (415) 393-0707


All you have to say, I'm a constituent and I'm asking:

+Vote "YES" on the Dodd-Feingold amendment, which would strip telecom
immunity from the bill entirely.

+Vote "YES" on the Bingaman amendment, which would delay implementation of
telecom immunity until after Congress has received the Inspectors General
report on the President's warrantless surveillance program.



Unfortunately, Obama and McCain are both planning to vote for the final
measure providing immunity to Telecoms!

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>

Subject: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT


"A human being is a part of the whole, called by us, "Universe," a  
part limited in time and space. He experiences himself, his thoughts  
and feelings as something separated from the rest -- a kind of optical  
delusion of his consciousness. This delusion is a kind of prison for  
us, restricting us to our personal desires and to affection for a few  
persons nearest to us. Our task must be to free ourselves from this  
prison by widening our circle of compassion to embrace all living  
creatures and the whole of nature in its beauty. Nobody is able to  
achieve this completely, but the striving for such achievement is in  
itself a part of the liberation and a foundation for inner  
security." : Albert Einstein - (1879-1955) Physicist and Professor,  
Nobel Prize 1921

I don't think there is evidence that Einstein considered himself a  
Buddhist.  However:


"Buddhism has the characteristics of what would be expected in a cosmic
religion of the future. It transcends a personal God, avoids dogmas and
theology; it covers both the natural and spiritual, and it is based on a
religious sense aspiring from the experience of all things, natural and
spiritual, as a meaningful unity."

-Einstein

--0-269644461-1215449535=:75508
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Good Morning SFR,

Hope everyone is in better shape this morning than I am!!!

Have you heard of Alex Grey? I just watched a DVD about his work this weekend called MindArt. This guy's philosophy is that if there is art which can depress the immune system, there is art which can heal & strengthen it as well. . . Pretty cool stuff! I must have watched his DVD like three (3) times! Amongst other works, he's done an album cover for Tool.

I'd HIGHLY recommend you run an image search on Google for Alex Grey if you haven't heard of him already. I've seen a lot of psychoactive artwork at parties that resemble his works, but nothing (IMHO) compares to the genuine article.

peace!

Chuck



      
--0-269644461-1215449535=:75508--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT

I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about. 

Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some cases even contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is the martial art encodes a teaching in its movements.  

Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts and meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors include some sitting meditation in their practices anyway.  

Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one form of meditation and their are more active forms which include movement, in some cases movements derived from martial arts.

Regards,

Peter

Eight forces sustain creation:
Movement and stillness,
Solidification and fluidity,
Extension and contraction,
Unification and division.
-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace


The Art of Peace does not rely on weapons or brute force to succeed;
instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in
our own realms, nurture life, and prevent death and destruction. The
true meaning of the term samurai is one who serves and adheres to the power of love.
-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace

>additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT

I almost forgot to mention that it is a mistaken view that meditation is just sitting around with a blank mind...most of the meditation I do requires active visualization of complex forms.  You have to memorize these forms from pictures and texts, and it takes extensive practice over time to do it accurately.  Its not anything like just "sitting around" as you state.

Peter



----- Original Message ----
From: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>; SFRaves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, July 7, 2008 3:50:06 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT

I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about. 

Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some cases even contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is the martial art encodes a teaching in its movements.  

Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts and meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors include some sitting meditation in their practices anyway.  

Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one form of meditation and their are more active forms which include movement, in some cases movements derived from martial arts.

Regards,

Peter

Eight forces sustain creation:
Movement and stillness,
Solidification and fluidity,
Extension and contraction,
Unification and division.
-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace


The Art of Peace does not rely on weapons or brute force to succeed;
instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in
our own realms, nurture life, and prevent death and destruction. The
true meaning of the term samurai is one who serves and adheres to the power of love.
-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace



----- Original Message ----
From: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Sunday, July 6, 2008 10:17:24 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT

I would say that about martial arts before buddhism, but I'd also say 
you'll find out more about your mind by testing it than by sitting 
around meditating.


s

At 09:00 PM 7/6/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>tripped of its cultural ornamentation, Buddhism presents what can 
>accurately be called a "science of mind".  To the extent that this 
>science accurately reflects the true nature of the universe, it is 
>quite attractive to scientists and is compatible with scientific 
>reasoning, evolution, and so forth.  It either works or it doesn't 
>work, and you can test it yourself.  IMO.  YMMV. Regards, Peter

That would depend on what shape you're in... :)

Note to the wise (or foolish) be VERY careful about preloading.  Technically
there's no risk to a combo of L-Tryptophan, Aniracetam and Choline...
(nutritional supplements all, available at GNC and even many drugstores)

> I almost forgot to mention that it is a mistaken view that meditation is just
> sitting around with a blank mind...most of the meditation I do requires active
> visualization of complex forms.  You have to memorize these forms from pictures
> and texts, and it takes extensive practice over time to do it accurately.  Its
> not anything like just "sitting around" as you state.
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> 
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>

> Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT
> 
> I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about. 
> 
> Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some cases even
> contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is the martial art encodes
> a teaching in its movements.  
> 
> Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts and
> meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors include some
> sitting meditation in their practices anyway.  
> 
> Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one form of
> meditation and their are more active forms which include movement, in some
> cases movements derived from martial arts.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Peter
> 
> Eight forces sustain creation:
> Movement and stillness,
> Solidification and fluidity,
> Extension and contraction,
> Unification and division.
> -- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art
> of Peace
> 
> 
> The Art of Peace does not rely on weapons or brute force to succeed;
> instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in
> our own realms, nurture life, and prevent death and destruction. The
> true meaning of the term samurai is one who serves and adheres to the power of
> love.
> -- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art
> of Peace
> 
>

So what I'm wondering is what did the relentless gloomy skulls that 
were endlessly repeated on the screen at Mighty last Saturday do to us?

and butterflies and flowers, so I remember thinking "Huh? What's up 
with the gloomy death imagery?"

Great DJs none the less! Had great time!

At 09:52 AM 7/7/2008, CHUCK G wrote:
>Good Morning SFR,
>
>Hope everyone is in better shape this morning than I am!!!
>
>Have you heard of Alex Grey? I just watched a DVD about his work 
>this weekend called MindArt. This guy's philosophy is that if there 
>is art which can depress the immune system, there is art which can 
>heal & strengthen it as well. . . Pretty cool stuff! I must have 
>watched his DVD like three (3) times! Amongst other works, he's done 
>an album cover for Tool.
>
>I'd HIGHLY recommend you run an image search on Google for Alex Grey 
>if you haven't heard of him already. I've seen a lot of psychoactive 
>artwork at parties that resemble his works, but nothing (IMHO) 
>compares to the genuine article.
>
>peace!
>
>Chuck
>
>
>

The greatest achievement is selflessness.
The greatest worth is self-mastery.
The greatest quality is seeking to serve others.
The greatest precept is continual awareness.
The greatest medicine is the emptiness of everything.
The greatest action is not conforming with the world's ways.
The greatest action is transmuting the passions.
The greatest generosity is non-attachment.
The greatest goodness is a peaceful mind.
The greatest patience is humility.
The greatest effort is not concerned with results.
The greatest meditation is a mind that lets go.
The greatest wisdom is seeing through appearances.

Atisha



apollo@speakeasy.org
MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"One of the strongest motives that lead men to art and science is escape from 
everyday life with its painful crudity and hopeless dreariness, from the 
fetters of one's own ever-shifting desires."-EINSTEIN

"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you upon 
the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!" - W.B.YEATS

> > >would be expected in a cosmic religion of the future. It transcends
> > >a personal God, avoids dogmas and theology; it covers both the
> > >natural and spiritual, and it is based on a religious sense aspiring
> > >from the experience of all things, natural and spiritual, as a
> > >meaningful unity." -Einstein On Jul 6, 2008, at 4:49 PM,
> > >littleetoile@aol.com wrote: > > Hmmm... didn't realize that
> > Einstein
> > >was Buddhist... ;) > > > > > -----Original Message----- >

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 

 

 

Subject: [SpAzLiSt] RIP DJ Tron

 

DJ Tron passed away on Friday from unknown causes but it was ruled an
"accident," whatever that means. He produced and DJed various forms of
hardcore and acid as well as made techno under the guise of "Demonslut." If
you were into that sort of thing, he was very popular in the late 90s. He
put out some excellent records and mixtapes over the years. Here's a link to
a few:

 

DJ Tron - Fucking Hardcore (side A)
http://www.sendspace.com/file/kq4gff

Fucking Hardcore (side B)
http://www.sendspace.com/file/w4nu7x

DJ Tron - Fucking Harder than the Devil Himself (side A)
http://www.sendspace.com/file/o36tj2
 


Fucking Harder then the Devil Himself (side B)
http://www.sendspace.com/file/xaoay0

DJ Tron - Fucking Silver Box (100% ACID)
http://www.sendspace.com/file/u51zp4 

 

Below is the official announcement of his death...

 

 

 

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: mirsch <mirsch13@hotmail.com>
Date: Jul 6, 2008 10:54 PM
Subject: Re: [gabber] RIP DJ Tron
To: gabber@hyperreal.org


To clear things up for everyone, Jeff aka DJ Tron did NOT die from an
overdose. It has been determined as an accidental death as of now... Read
below.

DJ Tron was my best friend, mentor, brother and room mate. At 1:30 a.m. July
4th, 2008 Jeff was found in my studio completely unresponsive. At that time
peramedics were called and I attempted to perform CPR but was unsuccessful.
At 2:15 a.m. the hospital prenounced his death. I've been in close contatact
several times a day with his mother "Momma Tron" and she stated that after
the police performed a thorough investigation of the living premisis, and
DuPage county coroners office performed a preliminary medical examination,
his sudden death has been determined accidental. As with all accidential
deaths the coroners final report will be avalible in 8 to 10 weeks. They do
not anticipate any other findings. These rumors of overdose are hurtful to
his family and friends closest to him and should be stopped immediately per
Momma Tron.

Lets just knock off the shit and remember Jeff as our General in hardcore
and the possitive influance and leadership he has had on all of us in the
industry for over the past 15 years.

R.I.P

Jeff Tron

7/29/1973 - 7/4/2008

<p class=3DMsoNormal style=3D'margin-left:.5in'>DJ Tron passed away on =
Friday from
unknown causes but it was ruled an &quot;accident,&quot; whatever that
means.&nbsp;He&nbsp;produced and DJed&nbsp;various forms of hardcore and
acid&nbsp;as well as&nbsp;made techno under the guise of =
&quot;Demonslut.&quot;
If you were into that sort of thing, he was very popular in the late =
90s. He
put out some excellent records and mixtapes over the years. Here's a =
link to a
few:<o:p></o:p></p>

<br>
To clear things up for everyone, Jeff aka DJ Tron did NOT die from =
an<br>
overdose. It has been determined as an accidental death as of now... =
Read<br>
below.<br>
<br>
DJ Tron was my best friend, mentor, brother and room mate. At 1:30 a.m. =
July<br>
4th, 2008 Jeff was found in my studio completely unresponsive. At that =
time<br>
peramedics were called and I attempted to perform CPR but was =
unsuccessful.<br>
At 2:15 a.m. the hospital prenounced his death. I've been in close =
contatact<br>
several times a day with his mother &quot;Momma Tron&quot; and she =
stated that
after<br>
the police performed a thorough investigation of the living premisis, =
and<br>
DuPage county coroners office performed a preliminary medical =
examination,<br>
his sudden death has been determined accidental. As with all =
accidential<br>
deaths the coroners final report will be avalible in 8 to 10 weeks. They =
do<br>
not anticipate any other findings. These rumors of overdose are hurtful =
to<br>
his family and friends closest to him and should be stopped immediately =
per<br>
Momma Tron.<br>
<br>
Lets just knock off the shit and remember Jeff as our General in =
hardcore<br>
and the possitive influance and leadership he has had on all of us in =
the<br>
industry for over the past 15 years.<br>
<br>
R.I.P<br>
<br>
Jeff Tron<br>
<br>
7/29/1973 - 7/4/2008<br>
<br>
<br>

At 03:50 PM 7/7/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about.
>
>Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some 
>cases even contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is 
>the martial art encodes a teaching in its movements.

+1 Me.

>Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts 
>and meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors 
>include some sitting meditation in their practices anyway.

I wasn't comparing meditation and martial arts, I was comparing 
buddhism and martial arts.  Also, a comparison doesn't result in an 
either / or choice.

>Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one 
>form of meditation and their are more active forms which include 
>movement, in some cases movements derived from martial arts.

If they're post martial arts, then they are def. post buddhism.


sarilion

>meditation I do requires active visualization of complex forms.  You

>extensive practice over time to do it accurately.  Its not anything 
>like just "sitting around" as you state.

>Eight forces sustain creation:
>Movement and stillness,
>Solidification and fluidity,
>Extension and contraction,
>Unification and division.
>-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace
>
>
>The Art of Peace does not rely on weapons or brute force to succeed;
>instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in
>our own realms, nurture life, and prevent death and destruction. The
>true meaning of the term samurai is one who serves and adheres to 
>the power of love.
>-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace
>
>

>At 09:00 PM 7/6/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> >tripped of its cultural ornamentation, Buddhism presents what can
> >accurately be called a "science of mind".  To the extent that this
> >science accurately reflects the true nature of the universe, it is
> >quite attractive to scientists and is compatible with scientific
> >reasoning, evolution, and so forth.  It either works or it doesn't
> >work, and you can test it yourself.  IMO.  YMMV. Regards, Peter

Subject: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?



As some of you may remember, I've been positing that the existing channels
of promotion simply aren't reaching enough people for quite some time now.

Just met someone online for other reasons, who would seem to be part of
this untapped audience:
> The city needs some more techno. Maybe step up the promotions if you can because seriously haven't heard about it! Dang and I'm like one of the 10 techno headz in SF buhaha. Just curious do you book lots of out of town DJs, or if it's locals could I ask who? I just so rarely hear of techno parties in SF and usually if I do it's the heavies Richie Hawtin, Magda, and if we're lucky one of the Detroit crew.

She's clearly paying attention to something because she knew about Hawtin,
but with all the other parties out there, how are we all missing the target?

Yes, I'm following up on her for multiple reasons, but how are we all missing
the boat here?

discuss. :)

-R.

At 03:57 PM 7/7/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>I almost forgot to mention that it is a mistaken view that 
>meditation is just sitting around with a blank mind...most of the 
>meditation I do requires active visualization of complex forms.  You 
>have to memorize these forms from pictures and texts, and it takes 
>extensive practice over time to do it accurately.  Its not anything 
>like just "sitting around" as you state.
>
>Peter
>
>
>
>----- Original Message ----
>From: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
>To: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>; SFRaves@hyperreal.org
>Sent: Monday, July 7, 2008 3:50:06 PM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT
>
>I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about.
>
>Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some 
>cases even contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is 
>the martial art encodes a teaching in its movements.
>
>Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts 
>and meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors 
>include some sitting meditation in their practices anyway.
>
>Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one 
>form of meditation and their are more active forms which include 
>movement, in some cases movements derived from martial arts.
>
>Regards,
>
>Peter
>
>Eight forces sustain creation:
>Movement and stillness,
>Solidification and fluidity,
>Extension and contraction,
>Unification and division.
>-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace
>
>
>The Art of Peace does not rely on weapons or brute force to succeed;
>instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in
>our own realms, nurture life, and prevent death and destruction. The
>true meaning of the term samurai is one who serves and adheres to 
>the power of love.
>-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace
>
>

----- Original Message ----
From: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, July 7, 2008 9:52:15 AM
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Alex Grey- MindArt

Good Morning SFR,

Hope everyone is in better shape this morning than I am!!!

Have you heard of Alex Grey? I just watched a DVD about his work this weekend called MindArt. This guy's philosophy is that if there is art which can depress the immune system, there is art which can heal & strengthen it as well. . . Pretty cool stuff! I must have watched his DVD like three (3) times! Amongst other works, he's done an album cover for Tool.

I'd HIGHLY recommend you run an image search on Google for Alex Grey if you haven't heard of him already. I've seen a lot of psychoactive artwork at parties that resemble his works, but nothing (IMHO) compares to the genuine article.

peace!

Chuck

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?

------=_Part_19403_15850286.1215542632240
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I feel kinda obligated to mention the DEF techno list here - def-announce-
subscribe@defsf.com
It's been going strong for around 5 years or so, and is just for Bay Area
and West Coast techno events, news, etc etc.

But what I was thinking was... Do you really want to promote to *everyone*?
 Sometimes it's more about reaching the right people, not a larger quantity
of people. When I first started throwing parties, I naively assumed that
people would like techno if only they were exposed to it, so I was all about
reaching as large of an audience as possible.  I learned pretty quickly
that's not really how it works...!  At one party, I overheard one raver say
to another, in regards to the all-techno lineup, "What the fuck is this
shit? I want some fuckin' TRANCE!"   I still laugh about that one...

And furthermore, I don't think that having a few low-turnout parties is
necessarily evidence of not having enough channels to promote.  Parties just
tank sometimes (uhh... all the time!).  There are tons of factors that make
a successful or unsuccessful event, not just the amount of promotion. Also,
remember there are 1,034,783,402,349 techno parties in the Bay Area every
week, happening nearly every single night. I feel like the techno club
market is saturated. I'm not about to hit every single run-of-the-mill
techno club night every week, Tuesday through Sunday.

These promoter discussions are sort of funny.  We're this promoter scene
that promotes to promoters. Where have all the ravers gone?  (Gone to
promoters every one?)

-Chelsea

> > >
> > > Yes, I'm following up on her for multiple reasons, but how
> > > are we all missing
> > > the boat here?
> > >
> > > discuss. :)
> > >
> > > -R.

p into more resources? Yes. But from the standpoint of a crew of two guys w=
ho does their own promotion and (typically) have day jobs=2C it's not easy =

l to hit every single cyber-avenue possible to promote. I have huge list of=
 lists and sites to promote to every other week=2C and I can barely keep up=
 with it.=20

Anyway=2C the point is - either folks aren't paying enough attention=2C or =
quite possibly promoters just don't have the time=2C money or patience to g=
o all the lengths possible to promote their gigs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?

------=_Part_13365_367476.1215543356203
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

places i know for promoting and/or hearing about techno in SF....

***email lists
sfraves list
defsf list

***online forums
blipswitch.net
groundscore.net (non dnb/dubstep forum)

***events websites
nitevibe
sfstation
flavorpill (if they select your event)
going.com
upcoming.org
nitewise
craigslist

***social networks
myspace
facebook
tribe

***and don't forget the good old fashioned staples....
postering @ parties
postering on telephone poles etc in the haight (i've got #s for the guys)
hand-to-hand flyering!


as michael mentioned, i also keep an informal calendar of events that i
think look cool/interesting and post it on the myspace bulletin board from
time to time. if you want access to it, send me a friend request and watch
the bulletin board.  i usually send the same updates from our kontrol
profile, so if i don't know you, i'd prefer you add that one.  i try to keep
my personal profile to mostly people i actually know.

profiles here:
http://www.myspace.com/bird415
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

there are lots of other online sites that can be hit (resident advisor,
ibiza-voice, tranceaddict, yadda yadda) but if you're looking for frequently
updated listings of LOCAL techno, i'd prolly recommend blipswitch and/or the
myspace bulletin board (assuming your friends with some techno-minded
folks/parties).

ray, my feeling is that the girl you spoke with really hasn't been trying
too hard.  if she was she'd know she's not one of the "10 techno headz in
SF".

for all of you who are about to say "yeah but all that shit's too minimal
for me... where's the REAL techno in SF?" please know, we don't
discriminate!  we book stuff we like.  if its not your bag, round up some
friends, book djs you want to see, throw a party, promote the hell out of
it, and hope for the best.  it CAN be done, as the bassaholics anonymous,
defsf, and platform crews, amongst others, have shown.

----->gb

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?

Chel-C's comment on not needing to reach every soul on earth is straight up.
I think most rave promoters are still operating in the 90s (funny how
that works..) marketing headspace. that is: impressions. Reaching as
many people as possible. Most effective promotion is word of mouth
promotion; person to person. You guys just need to reach your
lighthouse customers, the ones who will talk to everyone else...

In fact, seeing flyers for a party everywhere I go kind of discourages
me from going..
sean

>At 03:57 PM 7/7/2008, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>>I almost forgot to mention that it is a mistaken view that 
>>meditation is just sitting around with a blank mind...most of the 
>>meditation I do requires active visualization of complex forms.  You 
>>have to memorize these forms from pictures and texts, and it takes 
>>extensive practice over time to do it accurately.  Its not anything 
>>like just "sitting around" as you state.
>>
>>Peter

>>----- Original Message ----

>>I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about.
>>
>>Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some 
>>cases even contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is 
>>the martial art encodes a teaching in its movements.
>>
>>Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts 
>>and meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors 
>>include some sitting meditation in their practices anyway.
>>
>>Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one 
>>form of meditation and their are more active forms which include 
>>movement, in some cases movements derived from martial arts.
>>
>>Regards,
>>
>>Peter
>>
>>Eight forces sustain creation:
>>Movement and stillness,
>>Solidification and fluidity,
>>Extension and contraction,
>>Unification and division.
>>-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace
>>
>>
>>The Art of Peace does not rely on weapons or brute force to succeed;
>>instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in
>>our own realms, nurture life, and prevent death and destruction. The
>>true meaning of the term samurai is one who serves and adheres to 
>>the power of love.
>>-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The Art of Peace

Greg Bird wrote:
> places i know for promoting and/or hearing about techno in SF....
>
> ***email lists
> sfraves list
> defsf list
>
> ***online forums
> blipswitch.net
> groundscore.net (non dnb/dubstep forum)
>
> ***events websites
> nitevibe
> sfstation
> flavorpill (if they select your event)
> going.com
> upcoming.org
> nitewise
> craigslist
>
> ***social networks
> myspace
> facebook
> tribe
>
> ***and don't forget the good old fashioned staples....
> postering @ parties
> postering on telephone poles etc in the haight (i've got #s for the guys)
> hand-to-hand flyering!
>
>
> as michael mentioned, i also keep an informal calendar of events that i
> think look cool/interesting and post it on the myspace bulletin board from
> time to time. if you want access to it, send me a friend request and watch
> the bulletin board.  i usually send the same updates from our kontrol
> profile, so if i don't know you, i'd prefer you add that one.  i try to keep
> my personal profile to mostly people i actually know.
>
> profiles here:
> http://www.myspace.com/bird415
> http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf
>
> there are lots of other online sites that can be hit (resident advisor,
> ibiza-voice, tranceaddict, yadda yadda) but if you're looking for frequently
> updated listings of LOCAL techno, i'd prolly recommend blipswitch and/or the
> myspace bulletin board (assuming your friends with some techno-minded
> folks/parties).
>
> ray, my feeling is that the girl you spoke with really hasn't been trying
> too hard.  if she was she'd know she's not one of the "10 techno headz in
> SF".
>
> for all of you who are about to say "yeah but all that shit's too minimal
> for me... where's the REAL techno in SF?" please know, we don't
> discriminate!  we book stuff we like.  if its not your bag, round up some
> friends, book djs you want to see, throw a party, promote the hell out of
> it, and hope for the best.  it CAN be done, as the bassaholics anonymous,
> defsf, and platform crews, amongst others, have shown.
>
> ----->gb
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

Thanks for sharing apollo.

I was recently wondering what happened to DjTron as I was a huge fan of 
his way back when. I wasn't certain even if he was still producing 
anymore so I spent some time trying to track him down on the internet 
for no reason other than to see what he was up to.

And then this news.

I've posted one of his albums that I just ripped if anyone feels like 
some terrorcore/gabber/hardcore:

http://www.bookofgray.com/mptree/djtron_chrom_padded_cell

-tim

Apollo wrote:
>
>  
>
>  
>
>  
>
> *Subject:* [SpAzLiSt] RIP DJ Tron
>
>  
>
> DJ Tron passed away on Friday from unknown causes but it was ruled an 
> "accident," whatever that means. He produced and DJed various forms of 
> hardcore and acid as well as made techno under the guise of 
> "Demonslut." If you were into that sort of thing, he was very popular 
> in the late 90s. He put out some excellent records and mixtapes over 
> the years. Here's a link to a few:
>
>  
>
> DJ Tron - Fucking Hardcore (side A)
> http://www.sendspace.com/file/kq4gff
>
> Fucking Hardcore (side B)
> http://www.sendspace.com/file/w4nu7x
>
> DJ Tron - Fucking Harder than the Devil Himself (side A)
> http://www.sendspace.com/file/o36tj2
>  
>
>
> Fucking Harder then the Devil Himself (side B)
> http://www.sendspace.com/file/xaoay0
>
> DJ Tron - Fucking Silver Box (100% ACID)
> http://www.sendspace.com/file/u51zp4
>
>  
>
> Below is the official announcement of his death...
>
>  
>
>  
>
>  
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: *mirsch* <mirsch13@hotmail.com <mailto:mirsch13@hotmail.com>>
> Date: Jul 6, 2008 10:54 PM
> Subject: Re: [gabber] RIP DJ Tron
> To: gabber@hyperreal.org <mailto:gabber@hyperreal.org>
>
>
> To clear things up for everyone, Jeff aka DJ Tron did NOT die from an
> overdose. It has been determined as an accidental death as of now... Read
> below.
>
> DJ Tron was my best friend, mentor, brother and room mate. At 1:30 
> a.m. July
> 4th, 2008 Jeff was found in my studio completely unresponsive. At that 
> time
> peramedics were called and I attempted to perform CPR but was 
> unsuccessful.
> At 2:15 a.m. the hospital prenounced his death. I've been in close 
> contatact
> several times a day with his mother "Momma Tron" and she stated that after
> the police performed a thorough investigation of the living premisis, and
> DuPage county coroners office performed a preliminary medical examination,
> his sudden death has been determined accidental. As with all accidential
> deaths the coroners final report will be avalible in 8 to 10 weeks. 
> They do
> not anticipate any other findings. These rumors of overdose are hurtful to
> his family and friends closest to him and should be stopped 
> immediately per
> Momma Tron.
>
> Lets just knock off the shit and remember Jeff as our General in hardcore
> and the possitive influance and leadership he has had on all of us in the
> industry for over the past 15 years.
>
> R.I.P
>
> Jeff Tron
>
> 7/29/1973 - 7/4/2008
>
>
>
>
>  
>
