----- Original Message ----
From: Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, July 8, 2008 2:09:01 PM
Subject: [sfraves] The Gathering, Freedom, and Basics sets for download

I apologise if this has already been posted but thought this was important to share as I did not see this here yet. 
It looks like Martin has updated the Gathering website with tons of live sets for download from a bunch of old school Gathering, Freedom and Basics parties from 92-2007. These sets/parties were my education in house music and I know many of you here hold a special place in your heart for these as I do so I wanted to make sure this list is aware they are available. Looks like they are broken down by year, then party, then individual set. Here's the link. Again sorry if this has already been posted but I didn't see it.
 http://www.thegathering-sf.com/
 Dowload my latest mixes here:
www.musicv2.com/artist/dj_kevin_james
New mix added 5/17/08


Watch me spin live here Saturdays 3-5PM PST 6-8 EST
www.stickam.com/faderwaveradio


Baba Booey!!!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?



Yep, about the same list I use. :)  I gave up on tribe as it's just too
chaotic to choose by group instead of genre, and I don't like hitting everyone.


On Tue, Jul 08, 2008 at 11:55:56AM -0700, Greg Bird wrote:
> places i know for promoting and/or hearing about techno in SF....
> 
> ***and don't forget the good old fashioned staples....
> postering @ parties
> postering on telephone poles etc in the haight (i've got #s for the guys)
> hand-to-hand flyering!

Yep.  I've gotten a lot of new folks this way.  Most especially the ones
who've recently moved to the area and don't have a starting context.

> ray, my feeling is that the girl you spoke with really hasn't been trying
> too hard.  if she was she'd know she's not one of the "10 techno headz in
> SF".

Bit of that, yes.  She's a musician who's mostly wired into glitchy industrial
and some ambient-like stuff, so she's actually buried in her own scene and
wondering why there's no techno there. :)


However, I've met a lot of folks over the last 6 months or so who, if they
moved to SF in the last year, simply don't know where to start.  I agree
that maximizing impressions misses the point, but given the dyamic nature
of SF's population, there are a lot of these folks.  Hell, some folks who
came to the first faktion party have already moved out of town again.

I'm also running into some folks who're even more trapped in the 90s than
most of us.  The continued blurring of the line between house and techno
turns a lot of them off.  Of course, my problem here is that I think the
first priority of a party is to have fun, not get stuck in some theoretical
issue of exactly which genre every track is.  I've got no problems booking
the housier and trancier sounding DJs if I like their shit, yet I also love
booking hard techno DJs, and yeah, I will probably return to minimal very
soon now. :)

SRSLY, I still think there's a problem of reach.  I'm NOT a great promoter,
(or at least there are plenty of you guys who're better at it than I am)
and yet I'm still finding a fair chunk of these folks.  Yeah, a lot of them
really just aren't trying, but a good number of them are and just don't
know where to start looking.  It's not a matter of hitting more eyeballs,
though I have hit the chron folks a few times and gotten a few responses
there too -- just a matter of being too expensive for the few people I
wanted to reach, there.  I suppose in some ways it's just the price of
living in a city as diverse in SF.  This girl isn't really one of 10 heads,
she's just one of the 10 heads in her microcosm.

I just still think there are ways to find and meet these people who really
do like techno, if we can figure out how to target those we've never met
before.  Call it the startup guy in me. :)

-R.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?

I don't promote anything, I help organize events ;)

All the event organizers I know started out as ravers, and all the 
"promoters" I met when I was a raver were previously ravers.  It's a 
cycle.  The people I learned from aren't doing much these days.  New 
people step up to fill in, and a new generation of ravers commences.

I think there're ravers on this list that don't participate in these 
discussions, and just lurk.

and then there's Terry.


sarilion

At 11:43 AM 7/8/2008, Chelsea Faith wrote:
>I feel kinda obligated to mention the DEF techno list here - def-announce-
>subscribe@defsf.com
>It's been going strong for around 5 years or so, and is just for Bay Area
>and West Coast techno events, news, etc etc.
>
>But what I was thinking was... Do you really want to promote to *everyone*?
>  Sometimes it's more about reaching the right people, not a larger quantity
>of people. When I first started throwing parties, I naively assumed that
>people would like techno if only they were exposed to it, so I was all about
>reaching as large of an audience as possible.  I learned pretty quickly
>that's not really how it works...!  At one party, I overheard one raver say
>to another, in regards to the all-techno lineup, "What the fuck is this
>shit? I want some fuckin' TRANCE!"   I still laugh about that one...
>
>And furthermore, I don't think that having a few low-turnout parties is
>necessarily evidence of not having enough channels to promote.  Parties just
>tank sometimes (uhh... all the time!).  There are tons of factors that make
>a successful or unsuccessful event, not just the amount of promotion. Also,
>remember there are 1,034,783,402,349 techno parties in the Bay Area every
>week, happening nearly every single night. I feel like the techno club
>market is saturated. I'm not about to hit every single run-of-the-mill
>techno club night every week, Tuesday through Sunday.
>
>These promoter discussions are sort of funny.  We're this promoter scene
>that promotes to promoters. Where have all the ravers gone?  (Gone to
>promoters every one?)
>
>-Chelsea
>
>

Message-ID: <217532.87193.qm@web50004.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote?

> I just still think there are ways to find and meet these
> people who really
> do like techno, if we can figure out how to target those
> we've never met
> before.

when i first started going to parties, i had to do my own work.
 you know, go to clothing stores (ameba), record stores, shit
like that.

i'd find a party and talk with people there.  i would ask about
what was happening next week.  i'd go out to my car and have
like ten flyers on it.  soon, i'd identified the shady
promoters, the greedy promoters, the book-local-talent-only
promoters, etc.  i would start noting DJs i liked and going out
specifically to hear them, and would start going to certain
promoter's parties because of the high production value.  and i
did this with minimal internets.

i mean come on - today you can google most of this stuff and
come up with dirt on almost every popular DJ and a bunch of
their free mp3 sets.

i think these people we've never met before are lazy.

m


-----------------------------------------------------
 www.redstickman.com

 new downtempo mix online, you should check it out.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT

You wrote:

>I would say that about martial arts before buddhism, but I'd also say
>you'll find out more about your mind by testing it than by sitting
>around meditating.

Which sounds to me like an argument for the superiority of a specific technique or set of techniques.  "Testing it" over "sitting around meditating".

I don't accept that one technique is superior to all others, IMO it all depends on the person, their circumstances, and the specific situation.

"The goal of training in the martial arts is to overcome six kinds of
disease, 
	* the desire for victory, 
	* the desire to rely on technical cunning, 
	* the desire to show off, 
	* the desire to psychologically overwhelm the opponent, 
	* the desire to remain passive in order to wait for an opening, and 
	* the desire to become free of these diseases." 
--Yagyu Munenori 

Best,

Peter

Date: Tue, 08 Jul 2008 16:48:26 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
In-Reply-To: <596606.29282.qm@web32403.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
References: <596606.29282.qm@web32403.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT

you said that buddhism is science of the mind.

martial arts have distilled buddhism, and teach the science of the 
mind, as well as the science of the body.  buddhism is a great deal 
more than that.  therefore, I feel that if you're strictly going for 
"science of the mind," you're better served learning a martial art.

I don't accept enlightenment, so technique to reach it is 
irrelevant.  technique to achieve the best results from the science 
of mind and body is debatable.


s

> > >I almost forgot to mention that it is a mistaken view that
> > >meditation is just sitting around with a blank mind...most of the
> > >meditation I do requires active visualization of complex forms.  You
> > >have to memorize these forms from pictures and texts, and it takes
> > >extensive practice over time to do it accurately.  Its not anything
> > >like just "sitting around" as you state.
> > >
> > >Peter
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >----- Original Message ----
> > >From: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> > >To: Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>; SFRaves@hyperreal.org
> > >Sent: Monday, July 7, 2008 3:50:06 PM
> > >Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  THOUGHT
> > >
> > >I would respond that perhaps you don't know what you are talking about.
> > >
> > >Many martial arts are grounded in Buddhism or Taoism and in some
> > >cases even contain hidden Buddhist and Taoist symbology.  That is
> > >the martial art encodes a teaching in its movements.
> > >
> > >Also its not an either or choice; you can practice both marital arts
> > >and meditation.  In my experience many martial arts instructors
> > >include some sitting meditation in their practices anyway.
> > >
> > >Finally, I'll just point out that sitting meditation is only one
> > >form of meditation and their are more active forms which include
> > >movement, in some cases movements derived from martial arts.
> > >
> > >Regards,
> > >
> > >Peter
> > >
> > >Eight forces sustain creation:
> > >Movement and stillness,
> > >Solidification and fluidity,
> > >Extension and contraction,
> > >Unification and division.
> > >-- Morihei Ueshiba (founder of the "martial art" Aikido) from The
> > Art of Peace
> > >
> > >

> > >instead we put ourselves in tune with the universe, maintain peace in

-&e->> From: nico@viberation.com
-&e->> See below.
-&e->> 
-&e->> ----- Original Message ----- 
-&e->> From: "CHUCK G" 
-&e->> + Special opening set by Pinkko!

On Tue, 8 Jul 2008 electrofunk138@hotmail.com wrote:
-&e->
-&e->Unneccesary methinks. Even in jest.

I'm at a point where if someone is playing interesting music, I could give 
a fuck about a couple shibby mixes here and there.

Beatmatching is ultimately a fairly simple parlor trick (assuming your 
records are 4/4 enough, this can already be done fairly well by currently 
available software for you, yay~!).

DJing is the ability to select tunes (this should fall within the 
capabilities of anybody who has ever put an iTunes playlist together, and 
most modern cd players will play CDs with folders on them, whee... and 
most mp3/digital playback systems have that plus additional grouping 
heirarchies).

The ability to purchase easily, mix easily, organize tracks and seamlessly 
flow have all been made significantly easier by modern technologies like 
per channel EQ with deep cuts, cd/mp3 djing systems with pitch correction 
allowing greater than +/-8%, contemporary dance mixes which have easier 
mix cueing than ever, digital playlists and massive filesystems with 
integrated cuepoints, etc...

10 years ago, if a DJ trainwrecked, me and most people I know would wince, 
we'd talk shit, etc.  Now, I'm really really stoked with a DJ if they 
don't bore the living shit out of me, trainwrecks be damned.

Good luck Pinkko, find your own sound, do your own thing, and the 
dancefloor from a legion of eye-socket-buggeringly-boring DJs.  Worry more 
about finding your own voice and taking people somewhere that doesn't 
sound like everybody else, the technique comes in time, but good taste and 
a unique sound is something you should work on from day one.

andyw

p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I 
hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff 
that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck 
it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's 
just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance 
music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.  That shit is as 
bad as old handbag house for all the same reasons and nobody's had the 
balls to say so.  Something tells me I am ranting again, I'll go now.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

On Tue, Jul 8, 2008 at 5:19 PM, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

>
> -&e->> From: nico@viberation.com
> -&e->> See below.
> -&e->>

> -&e->> From: "CHUCK G"
> -&e->> + Special opening set by Pinkko!

> On Tue, 8 Jul 2008 electrofunk138@hotmail.com wrote:
> -&e->
> -&e->Unneccesary methinks. Even in jest.
>
> I'm at a point where if someone is playing interesting music, I could give
> a fuck about a couple shibby mixes here and there.
>
> Beatmatching is ultimately a fairly simple parlor trick (assuming your
> records are 4/4 enough, this can already be done fairly well by currently
> available software for you, yay~!).
>
> DJing is the ability to select tunes (this should fall within the
> capabilities of anybody who has ever put an iTunes playlist together, and
> most modern cd players will play CDs with folders on them, whee... and
> most mp3/digital playback systems have that plus additional grouping
> heirarchies).
>
> The ability to purchase easily, mix easily, organize tracks and seamlessly
> flow have all been made significantly easier by modern technologies like
> per channel EQ with deep cuts, cd/mp3 djing systems with pitch correction
> allowing greater than +/-8%, contemporary dance mixes which have easier
> mix cueing than ever, digital playlists and massive filesystems with
> integrated cuepoints, etc...
>
> 10 years ago, if a DJ trainwrecked, me and most people I know would wince,
> we'd talk shit, etc.  Now, I'm really really stoked with a DJ if they
> don't bore the living shit out of me, trainwrecks be damned.
>
> Good luck Pinkko, find your own sound, do your own thing, and the
> dancefloor from a legion of eye-socket-buggeringly-boring DJs.  Worry more
> about finding your own voice and taking people somewhere that doesn't
> sound like everybody else, the technique comes in time, but good taste and
> a unique sound is something you should work on from day one.
>
> andyw
>
> p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I
> hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff
> that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck
> it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's
> just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance
> music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.  That shit is as
> bad as old handbag house for all the same reasons and nobody's had the
> balls to say so.  Something tells me I am ranting again, I'll go now.
>

p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I 
hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff 
that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck

Amen, that sound got boring pretty quickly, it just doesn't have any dynamics, grates on the ear.  I always feel like I need to driving a camaro on poppers when I hear that stuff.  Also, I've heard you rail on "electro house" here and there, so you'll probably be happy to note that the genre has gone from something I found cool and dynamic to stinking on ice in the span of 6 months, and almost every track I buy now is classified as techno, or maybe tech house.

Electro House = Today's Big Beat, minus the star power.

The cycle begins again, lol,
-G

On Tue, Jul 8, 2008 at 5:35 PM, George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:

----- Original Message ----

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I
hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff
that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck
it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's
just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance
music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.

Amen, that sound got boring pretty quickly, it just doesn't have any dynamics, grates on the ear.  I always feel like I need to driving a camaro on poppers when I hear that stuff.  Also, I've heard you rail on "electro house" here and there, so you'll probably be happy to note that the genre has gone from something I found cool and dynamic to stinking on ice in the span of 6 months, and almost every track I buy now is classified as techno, or maybe tech house.

Electro House = Today's Big Beat, minus the star power.

The cycle begins again, lol,
-G

Subject: Re: [sfraves] so how else can we promote? ok.. more techno

I've had the links for the DEF-announce list in my signature for years. 
Shrug.

  I agree with stickman, you have to be out there actively seeking it 
out and KNOW YOUR SCENE before you come and say they ain't no scene.

  I also think there has been an underground techno scene for a reason, 
and that was to keep the snooty club attitudes out of the rave scene. 
But since techno has adapted itself to be more flexible outside a dark, 
one red light bulb lit warehouse, its been taking on aspects of other 
genres and challenging itself on what it could become, rather than what 
techno is not. i think techno used to be about, -not being trance, -not 
being house, -not being this and that, as a struggle for an identity in 
an exploding EDM scene in the 90s.. when its apparent that trance is 
DEAD (dead-dida-dead dead) and house sounds just like techno (or is it 
vice verse?), and techno seems to be evolving monthly again, the techno 
scene is just exploding with possibilities... its with these 
possibilities techno is becoming more fresh and it is  moving into 
unexpected places, like the club circuit. i.e. places where people will 
not expect techno and as a result, all sorts of people will come to be 
curious about it. Maybe this girl is just a newbe and has just been 
turned on? I feel with the influx of people from all over the world to 
SF on an annual basis, I as a born and raised norcal kid am feeling like 
its hard to keep up with all the new people wanting to join the techno 
scene and help it evolve. -but I also feel that's what makes it all so 
exciting! I love that there's so much fresh blood in the scene now.

Old people are coming back into the techno scene all over. Cool people 
from the midwest are heading out here to SF. The northwest techno scene 
is taking off and the droid list is pushing numbers past the thousands 
in LA. There are way more producers than DJs now and that's f'n cool 
which means that there will be a new techno sound evolving out here on 
the west coast. Eventually we will live in some exciting times in a 
musical sense, I predict... possibly rivaling Detroit's legacy and 
matching Berlin's influence.. maybe even starting something better and 
evolving into unimagined genres besides techno. Who knows?

peace love techno!!

Sean f*ckin Ocean

btw

http://www.defsf.com = techno `;P lol.

And when doesn't Alex Windsor kill it? I'd be very surprised if I 
*wasn't* sweaty and punch drunk at the end of one of his sets. Saying 
Alex sucks at DJing is like saying sex feels bad. lol `;)

Chelsea Faith wrote:
> I feel kinda obligated to mention the DEF techno list here -
def-announce-subscribe@defsf.com
> It's been going strong for around 5 years or so, and is just for Bay Area
> and West Coast techno events, news, etc etc.
>
> But what I was thinking was... Do you really want to promote to *everyone*?
>  Sometimes it's more about reaching the right people, not a larger quantity
> of people. When I first started throwing parties, I naively assumed that
> people would like techno if only they were exposed to it, so I was all about
> reaching as large of an audience as possible.  I learned pretty quickly
> that's not really how it works...!  At one party, I overheard one raver say
> to another, in regards to the all-techno lineup, "What the fuck is this
> shit? I want some fuckin' TRANCE!"   I still laugh about that one...
>
> And furthermore, I don't think that having a few low-turnout parties is
> necessarily evidence of not having enough channels to promote.  Parties just
> tank sometimes (uhh... all the time!).  There are tons of factors that make
> a successful or unsuccessful event, not just the amount of promotion. Also,
> remember there are 1,034,783,402,349 techno parties in the Bay Area every
> week, happening nearly every single night. I feel like the techno club
> market is saturated. I'm not about to hit every single run-of-the-mill
> techno club night every week, Tuesday through Sunday.
>
> These promoter discussions are sort of funny.  We're this promoter scene
> that promotes to promoters. Where have all the ravers gone?  (Gone to
> promoters every one?)
>
> -Chelsea
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!

yeah i want to hear some style out there. good point andy. when i was 
first going to raves i would just  totally be in tune with what a dj was 
playing if they tried hard and represented their own type of style. 
where you could hear and feel the difference between DJs as they stepped 
up to the decks and delivered. i'm not saying that you shouldn't try 
hard to mix as flawlessly as you can because that too is a sense of 
style and class but if i heard records that went somewhere and had a 
certain quality that another DJ lacked i'd be goin, 'damn that dj made 
my day.'

i think alot of Djs these days feel obligated to play out of a social 
obligation to promote the scene they are in. Rather than the promoter 
searching high and low to find this dj to rock the party cause this dj 
had a disco tan and wasn't getting heard. now its just djs throwing dj 
parties.  that's why i try to book myself for my own parties anymore 
unless its to save some guy from djing last.



AndyW wrote:
> -&e->> From: nico@viberation.com
> -&e->> See below.
> -&e->> 
> -&e->> ----- Original Message ----- 
> -&e->> From: "CHUCK G" 
> -&e->> + Special opening set by Pinkko!
>
> On Tue, 8 Jul 2008 electrofunk138@hotmail.com wrote:
> -&e->
> -&e->Unneccesary methinks. Even in jest.
>
> I'm at a point where if someone is playing interesting music, I could give 
> a fuck about a couple shibby mixes here and there.
>
> Beatmatching is ultimately a fairly simple parlor trick (assuming your 
> records are 4/4 enough, this can already be done fairly well by currently 
> available software for you, yay~!).
>
> DJing is the ability to select tunes (this should fall within the 
> capabilities of anybody who has ever put an iTunes playlist together, and 
> most modern cd players will play CDs with folders on them, whee... and 
> most mp3/digital playback systems have that plus additional grouping 
> heirarchies).
>
> The ability to purchase easily, mix easily, organize tracks and seamlessly 
> flow have all been made significantly easier by modern technologies like 
> per channel EQ with deep cuts, cd/mp3 djing systems with pitch correction 
> allowing greater than +/-8%, contemporary dance mixes which have easier 
> mix cueing than ever, digital playlists and massive filesystems with 
> integrated cuepoints, etc...
>
> 10 years ago, if a DJ trainwrecked, me and most people I know would wince, 
> we'd talk shit, etc.  Now, I'm really really stoked with a DJ if they 
> don't bore the living shit out of me, trainwrecks be damned.
>
> Good luck Pinkko, find your own sound, do your own thing, and the 
> dancefloor from a legion of eye-socket-buggeringly-boring DJs.  Worry more 
> about finding your own voice and taking people somewhere that doesn't 
> sound like everybody else, the technique comes in time, but good taste and 
> a unique sound is something you should work on from day one.
>
> andyw
>
> p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I 
> hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff 
> that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck 
> it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's 
> just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance 
> music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.  That shit is as 
> bad as old handbag house for all the same reasons and nobody's had the 
> balls to say so.  Something tells me I am ranting again, I'll go now.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] The Gathering, Freedom, and Basics sets for download

Yes.....:)   I had just downloaded the 1992 Josh set and was listening  
to it.  Brought back those candy-flipping days when we would begin  
dancing Friday night, go to the "Church," continue on Saturday night  
through Sunday night and go to work on Monday.  Every weekend and some  
weeknites. Wonderful!!!  Catches one on the back-end of life, tho, but  
if I had to do it all over again I'd do more of it.

So I'm back in the early nineties listening to Josh when I hear a  
siren outside.  Look out the window and the PG&E crew have  broken  
into a gas main right in front of my house.  Gas spewing into the  
air.  Fire trucks.  Police.  Rush to get my birds and discover the  
downstairs bedroom stinks of gas.  Bring them upstairs and seal  
windows.  Now it looks like the finally shut off the leak.  Everyone  
OK so far.

So back to the 20th century.  I have some tapes of sets I did at the  
Endup in those days.  Dekadence.  Uranus.  Legendary queer parties.  I  
keep meaning to put it all on CDs.  Better do it before I go up in  
smoke on of these days:)

Love,

Apollo

> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

>

"We're all afloat in a boundless sea,
and the way we cope is by massing together in groups and pretending in  
unison that the situation is other than it is. We reinforce the  
illusion for each other. That's what a society really is, a little  
band of humanity huddled together against the specter of a pitch black  
sea. Everyone is treading water to keep their heads above the surface  
even though they have no reason to believe that the life they're  
preserving is better than the alternative they're avoiding. It's just  
that one is known and one is not. Fear of the unknown is what keeps  
everyone busily treading water. All fear is fear of the unknown. If  
someone in such a group of water-treaders betrays the group lie by  
speaking the truth of their situation, that person is called a  
heretic, and society reserves its most awful punishments for heretics.  
If someone decides to stop struggling and just sink or float away,  
every possible effort is made to stop him, not for the benefit of the  
individual, but for the benefit of the group. To deny at all costs the  
truth of the situation."

J.McKenna


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

--

Folks, try this.  Go to the supermarket and look at the label.  If it  
says "natural flavoring", put it back.  Or, if you don't believe me,  
take it home, and call the company, and ask them what is in their  
"natural flavoring".  They will not tell you.

- Jeff Rense

Source:  Jeff Rense Show, 7/8/08, 3rd hour, interviewing Will Thomas,  
Zombie Nation/Chemtrail 1996-2008

Subject: [sfraves] Customer opinion about SF techno parties

--_242dca5d-0fa3-4e56-8a70-178c97958835_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


=20
Not sure if anyone has noticed or if anyone has thought about the possibili=
ty that techno music and any music that falls under it from the simplest te=
rm to the most detailed articulate description/definition is not the most p=
opular music of the day and the audience is not as large as many think espe=
cially if you are trying to make some $$$ off anything that has to do with =
that type of music. This is my opinion only!
=20
Although I somewhat doubt the majority of people who go out really care or =
pay attention to what is being played sometimes. They may be at the club be=
cause they like the music but not everyone is down for techno like people o=
n this list.=20
=20
For the most part when I think of going to some of the techno parties in SF=
 I picture a couple oriented scene and lots of dude on dude activity (no pu=
n intended for you gay dudes because you probably feel the same at an all s=
traight club). For a straight dude in SF going to techno parties well you g=
et the rest if you know what I mean it is hard to find a good party with ho=
t chicks and when you do the party gets labeled as some trendy party becaus=
e lots of hot chicks will not kick it in a warehouse. I will be making my s=
econd trip to Amsterdam next week for two weeks so fun times are ahead=85.=
=20
=20
Maybe I go to the wrong parties sometimes but undergrounds in sketchy hoods=
 are just liabilities for temporary fun. Not to mention I am old enough to =
get into a club so a party that I would have went to as a teen is not that =
appealing. In this day and age not knowing where the party is going to be u=
ntil you get a map or wait until a few hours before the info is released is=
 not that big of a deal and hardly surprising. I spend lots of money when I=
 go out so I try and choose where I go wisely and getting laid after workin=
g my balls off all week matters to me=85
=20
ISAAC
=20

Hahaha!

Isaac <greylane@hotmail.com> wrote: 
 
Not sure if anyone has noticed or if anyone has thought about the possibility that techno music and any music that falls under it from the simplest term to the most detailed articulate description/definition is not the most popular music of the day and the audience is not as large as many think especially if you are trying to make some $$$ off anything that has to do with that type of music. This is my opinion only!
 
Although I somewhat doubt the majority of people who go out really care or pay attention to what is being played sometimes. They may be at the club because they like the music but not everyone is down for techno like people on this list. 
 
For the most part when I think of going to some of the techno parties in SF I picture a couple oriented scene and lots of dude on dude activity (no pun intended for you gay dudes because you probably feel the same at an all straight club). For a straight dude in SF going to techno parties well you get the rest if you know what I mean it is hard to find a good party with hot chicks and when you do the party gets labeled as some trendy party because lots of hot chicks will not kick it in a warehouse. I will be making my second trip to Amsterdam next week for two weeks so fun times are ahead. 
 
Maybe I go to the wrong parties sometimes but undergrounds in sketchy hoods are just liabilities for temporary fun. Not to mention I am old enough to get into a club so a party that I would have went to as a teen is not that appealing. In this day and age not knowing where the party is going to be until you get a map or wait until a few hours before the info is released is not that big of a deal and hardly surprising. I spend lots of money when I go out so I try and choose where I go wisely and getting laid after working my balls off all week matters to me
 
ISAAC

At 05:35 PM 7/8/2008, George Cochrane wrote:
----- Original Message ----

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I
hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff
that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck
it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's
just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance
music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.
---

Amen, that sound got boring pretty quickly, it just doesn't have any dynamics, grates on the ear.  I always feel like I need to driving a camaro on poppers when I hear that stuff.  Also, I've heard you rail on "electro house" here and there, so you'll probably be happy to note that the genre has gone from something I found cool and dynamic to stinking on ice in the span of 6 months, and almost every track I buy now is classified as techno, or maybe tech house.

Electro House = Today's Big Beat, minus the star power.

The cycle begins again, lol,
-G

Date: Wed, 9 Jul 2008 08:51:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com, Red Stickman <red_stickman@yahoo.com>,
  Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
Cc: "sfraves@hyperreal.org" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <594020.85636.qm@web65413.mail.ac4.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!

Naw, I loved big beat- but I think it worked to a large degree because of the character and the larger-than-life-ness of its makers.  The sheer dollars spent making its producers into rockstars, putting on those huge tours, etc.

It was trashy, and there was a 10:1 ratio of shit to real gold in it, but the gold was great, and the cult of personality only made it more alluring.

Electro house is like that, to me, only the S:G ratio is FAR higher, and the producers are largely faceless (like most UG music), so there's no "Aww, this new Fatboy Slim track kind of sucks, but he's so great I guess I'll give it another listen".  It's just "OOGH, this sounds like a giant duck farting.  NEXT!".

The gold in electro house up til a few months ago was something I really dug.  I just feel like the "top tracxxxs" and djs in the genre at the moment are getting too arena-y for their britches, and consequently, if I were to drop one of their tracks at a club with less than a couple thousand people in it, I'd feel like a ripe d-bag.  Still love Dirtybird, still love lots of stuff.

It's not the music, it's the shifted boundaries.
-G

At 05:35 PM 7/8/2008, George Cochrane wrote:
----- Original Message ----

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I
hear the same shit.  and it sucks.  The world does not need more stuff
that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck
it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's
just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance
music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.
---

Amen, that sound got boring pretty quickly, it just doesn't have any dynamics, grates on the ear.  I always feel like I need to driving a camaro on poppers when I hear that stuff.  Also, I've heard you rail on "electro house" here and there, so you'll probably be happy to note that the genre has gone from something I found cool and dynamic to stinking on ice in the span of 6 months, and almost every track I buy now is classified as techno, or maybe tech house.

Electro House = Today's Big Beat, minus the star power.

The cycle begins again, lol,
-G

i don't go out to clubs to pick up chicks, and no, i don't go out to =20
clubs to pick up dudes, either, in case you were now wondering.  i =20
used to go out for the scene, but now i only pretty much go out for =20

suppose is to my detriment sometimes, because i don't get to know =20
people as well as i guess i could, and if i do have a conversation, =20

ground venues, without that meat-market vibe that one often feels in clubla=
nd.  Where people weren't drunk and puking, but (sometimes) high and gettin=
g their minds expanded.  Where the music, by and large, was of very high qu=
ality and dj choices were made on music first, politics second.=0A=0AMany o=
f us have, or still do, live in "sketchy" hoods because we like the culture=

parties you dig going to, and that's great!  =0A=0AI'm not a techno dj, pro=

> just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance
> music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.

> dynamics, grates on the ear.  I always feel like I need to driving a 
> camaro on poppers when I hear that stuff.  Also, I've heard you rail on 
> "electro house" here and there, so you'll probably be happy to note that 
> the genre has gone from something I found cool and dynamic to stinking on 
> ice in the span of 6 months, and almost every track I buy now is 
> classified as techno, or maybe tech house.
>
> Electro House = Today's Big Beat, minus the star power.
>
> The cycle begins again, lol,
> -G

I disagree that 'Electro House is crap.'  I believe the continued growing popularity of digital music, coupled with the popularity of the genre, has made it increasingly harder to find good Electro House.

A couple years ago you could dig through and find lots of great Electro House, now you have to dig through tons and tons of crap to find something decent.

-Phillip


Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org> wrote: I got that the first time around, I'm more surprised that he thinks 
Big Beat is crap.

I disagree on both counts.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!



>I disagree that 'Electro House is crap.'  I believe the continued growing 
>popularity of digital music, coupled with the popularity of the genre, has 
>made it increasingly harder to find good Electro House.

I could not agree more.  You had to have your shit together and know what 
you're doing in order to cut a track in the vinyl days.  While I'm not a 
vinyl-purist, I saw the value of that very early.

Because the tracks are so easily and accessible now during the digital era, 
it dillutes the quality of what's being played.  Rather than investing in 
your music, some DJs can just get by with a few pieces of nickel.

I think this has both helped and hurt EDM.  Some deserving people who 
wouldn't get exposure otherwise are getting attention, whereas some ... 
yeah.

love always

n i c o





---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!

Yeah, let it be known, I really do love lots of electro house.  I just feel the traditional guidelines of the genre have shifted significantly, and that one-note joke of "big sawtoothy bassline, pitched up and down, dirty mix, oooh big spooky breakdown" is TOO locked in to allow for much innovation.

It's like democrat and republican.  The mission and meaning behind them switch places every so often.  

I will happily buy any electro house that is awesome.  I'm just finding it hard to keep getting stoked on new stuff.  Hence, techno/tech house, which is where my attention lies now.

-G



----- Original Message ----
From: "electrofunk138@hotmail.com" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; Red Stickman <red_stickman@yahoo.com>; Sarilion <sarilion@sarilion.org>
Cc: "sfraves@hyperreal.org" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, July 9, 2008 2:39:14 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!



Electro-house like any other genre has crap in it. I have to chuckle at folks who always single out some particular genre to say how awful it is when it becomes super popular, considering every genre has had it's moment in the sun, and every genre has had it's share of crap tunes being churned out. 

About the only genres I have heard that consistantly suck massive hairy balls, are either gabber or happy hardcore - but, c'mon...we all knew that already! 

As with any genre, it's which tracks you pick and choose to spin...and seeing as how so many of the local breaks kids are now firmly wedged up the arse of electro-house, it's no big shock to me you hear the same shit out every single fucking time you go out. Those kids tend to cane to death the "top 10" tracks of the month or week or whatever. Now rather than doing it with breaks, they are just doing it with electro-house. Sad really seeing as how there's actually a ton of stuff in that genre that rocks pretty hard and it seems like me and fLOORCRAFT and some of the Bassyx kids are the only people really tapping into the better sounding shit right now....

Well said, Mr. Tummyluv.

I go out to hear good music and be around people I like and generally care
about, not to get laid. Though I'm not opposed to getting laid if the
opportunity presents itself. Really, I think most people that are really
into the 'scene' and have been for some time are more about the music than
anything else. Especially when they continue to go out even if they're not
wasted. Also, not every DJ is into the whole trying to be a superstar thing=
.
Some of us just like to play music.

:-)

I'm finding the same to be true of drum and bass. Especially the harder
stuff. Seems like everyone's putting out this awful, ringtone-step, jump
uppy bullshit with obnoxious basslines and uncreative drum loops. Good thing
I don't mind playing older shit, eh?

There's some pretty cool shit happening in dubstep, though it's not like any
of you fuckers would deign to listen to such an awful genre.

Also, gabber + hhc = sexytime romantic candy EXPLOSION!

On Wed, Jul 9, 2008 at 3:01 PM, pinkko <ealaughlin@gmail.com> wrote:

> Good thing
> I don't mind playing older shit, eh?
>
>
IMO, one of the benefits of the explosion of digital EDM in the past several
years is older stuff can still wind up sounding fresh.

There's so much out there that no one could possibly know it all; and a
track released two years ago that was ahead of its time--and under the
radar--can fit in neatly with more current material, and even the devoted
may not have heard it before. Every once in a while I come across a track
released as far back as 2001 that still sounds playable with stuff released
last week.

Damon

------=_Part_4334_30083615.1215641193371--

The one thing I loved about Record Shops is that you had a good idea of wha=
t
types of records they were buying, and the guy behind the counter could
usually guide you to lesser known stuff that you likely dug.

What rocks about beatport most, is also what makes them suck.  Their huge
selection.  I have the same problems as most of you have, going through
hundreds of songs, and maybe only picking up 5 of them.  I find myself
searching artists and labels much more often, and buying tracks that aren't
new releases because of the onslaught of crap that's on there.   Finding
lesser known gems has become more difficult, as I don't have the time to
listen to the 490 crappy new releases in a single subgenre on a daily basis
to find 10 decent ones.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!


Amen to that Ben.

I had two guys at Solid Grooves, one at Tweakin, one at Harmonics, one at 
Open Mind, even got a call every so often from Capricorn in SC... all 
looking out for shit they'd thought I'd like.  Plus weird hookups like 
Angel Alanis sending me whatever promos he got sent that he didn't like 
and whatever he was putting out cause I got him his first booking in SF.  
That whole chain hardly exists anymore (well, at least for me).

The value of the expensive to make "thing" has gone, and it's been good 
and bad in a lot of ways I don't think anybody anticipated.

A producer had less chance to put stuff out, and it was harder to make a 
track back then (producers had studios with mixers and samplers and 
effects racks, not just a computer, some monitors and a bunch of plugins).  
Then they had to get a label to press it.  Then a buyer/distributor to 
pick it up.  And a store to buy it.  Lots of quality control.  Yeah, it 
was somewhat corrupt and prone to edging out weird shit, but there were a 
lot more places for total garbage to get stuck in the channel before it 
got to the bins too.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\_________________
"I think the biggest misconception about me is that I'm this spoiled brat. 
But I'm not. I'm, like, the total opposite." - Paris Hilton

-&e->What rocks about beatport most, is also what makes them suck.  Their huge
-&e->selection.  I have the same problems as most of you have, going through
-&e->hundreds of songs, and maybe only picking up 5 of them.  I find myself
-&e->searching artists and labels much more often, and buying tracks that aren't
-&e->new releases because of the onslaught of crap that's on there.   Finding
-&e->lesser known gems has become more difficult, as I don't have the time to
-&e->listen to the 490 crappy new releases in a single subgenre on a daily basis
-&e->to find 10 decent ones.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Customer opinion about SF techno parties


On Tue, 8 Jul 2008, Isaac wrote:
-&e-> Not sure if anyone has noticed or if anyone has thought about the 
-&e->possibility that techno music and any music that falls under it from 
-&e->the simplest term to the most detailed articulate 
-&e->description/definition is not the most popular music of the day and 
-&e->the audience is not as large as many think especially if you are 
-&e->trying to make some $$$ off anything that has to do with that type of 
-&e->music. This is my opinion only!

Some techno is the fucking bomb.  What other people think, doesn't matter 
all that much to me.  Never did.  I got into it when my friends weren't 
into it, and I've had my just desserts time and time again when I took a 
party somewhere that no other genre could (I've also cleared some floors, 
but hey, if I love it and you don't sorry... it's what I do, shame on the 
promoter I guess).  I learned how to mix at house (not the genre but as in 
domocile) parties.  I came up not by scheming and plotting and promoting, 
but by making mixes a couple times a year and playing bigger and bigger 
parties.  I kept getting invited back.  I've played for the 5 people who 
are too ef'd up to sleep at 7 am at a cabin party, and I've played peak 
hour after John Selway for 5000 heads and just *aced* it.  Got involved 
with a couple crews.  Some of those crews are still going, pure as ever.  
And most every time, I played techno.  Not techno like the other word for 
"electronica", but the deep shit, drum machines and samplers with a groove 
in the 128-142 zone sounding nice and minimal and very synthetic with a 
bassline that bypasses your brain and direct hits yer arse... the sound of 
Berlin and Detroit and Stockholm and Lost and the tradition of No UFOs and 
Basic Channel and DJ Rush and Losing Control and Advent and No Way Back.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMshcL5P7vI
(god I love this record, wish more stuff on the techno/house edge grooved 
like this)

The money, well, it's nice and I guess I care sure... but not all that 
much.  I was never a big fan of the "professional musician".  I like music 
the same way I like sex, I love it enough that I'd rather have a day job 
and not make money off it.  Cause when you make money off it, you gotta do 
what mommy/daddy wants you to do rather than what gets you off, and I'd 
rather lose some money for the opportunity to keep it my way.  There was a 
time when I made some serious scrilla off DJing/doing sound in this town, 
those days are gone, I'm not crying.  It comes and it goes when you do 
what you want to rather than try to adjust to trends.  You say fuck the 
trends, and you end up having a record collection you love, even when 
you're not booked to play shit.  I've honestly reached a point where I'm 
just not that interested in DJing anymore... vinyl is dying, I can't be 
bothered with picking through thousands of pieces of crap on Beatport to 
get the good stuff, and if someone wants to hear what I sound like I'll 
just bomb my own shit off the laptop or outboard gear I wrote it on (I 
still write all the time).

-&e-> Although I somewhat doubt the majority of people who go out really 
-&e->care or pay attention to what is being played sometimes. They may be 
-&e->at the club because they like the music but not everyone is down for 
-&e->techno like people on this list.

I want the music to be important.  There are times when it isn't.  No 
biggy, if it's still a good time.  But when a promoter doesn't care about 
the music, they should stop promoting through the music scene and go the 
way of the dead city ULTRACLUBZ and just enjoy their lame ass $70 bottle 
service, butterface collagen hoes and some 15 year old Global Underground 
CD playing quietly in the background.  Get off SFR and promote at the Gold 
Club, at 1015, on the roofs of cabs picking up lonely businessmen from 
their "massages" and Nightvibe.com.  This started out not only as a "not a 
club" list, but as the antithesis of that entire vibe.  We were down with 
Full Moons, the Gathering, and Stompy, and Come-Unity and Sunset... but 
not that total clubber hookup shit (even though there were a strong 
contingent of peeps who LOVED going to house weeklies, we always drew a 
fine line between the pickup joint scene and the head down I LOVE HOUSE 
groovers).

Ugh, this stuff is just slaying me on a sunny day in SF in my backyard 
responding to SFR heheheh...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4iGqLaqsyXY
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kBnlBLfAdBY
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p18I11vE1nE

-&e->For the most part when I think of going to some of the techno parties 
-&e->in SF I picture a couple oriented scene and lots of dude on dude 
-&e->activity (no pun intended for you gay dudes because you probably feel 
-&e->the same at an all straight club). For a straight dude in SF going to 
-&e->techno parties well you get the rest if you know what I mean it is 
-&e->hard to find a good party with hot chicks and when you do the party 
-&e->gets labeled as some trendy party because lots of hot chicks will not 
-&e->kick it in a warehouse. I will be making my second trip to Amsterdam 
-&e->next week for two weeks so fun times are ahead?.

Congratulations on the paragraph most likely to troll me this year.  Say 
something homophobic and totally pointless, then appeal to your gay bros 
for clemency assuming they couldn't possibly have fun at a straight club.  
Congratulations on labeling anybody who might actually look at the DJ 
lineup or music as a reason for going out... guess it's all about TEH 
ARSE.

And on the "dude on dude" comments, do you have any idea where house music 
came from?  Know your history, seriously man.  While "real men" were 
burning disco records in baseball stadium riots, gay disco kept the groove 
by going underground and cheap... and the first step was losing the 
backing bands and making it with electronics.  Welcome to house music in 
the 80s, where all this came from pretty much.

Maybe, just maybe, when I'm on the dance floor it's me + music and whoever 
I see smiling and grooving and it's not sexual.  It's different, and the 
sexual/attraction bit has NEVER been why I was there.  Why do you think 
this underground happened in SF the way it did *right* as we had a 
thriving dance club scene?  Cause we got sick of oogling cokehead boring 
ass fuckface scenesters trying to find a place to park their dicks and 
hoochies hoping to hook some fucknut blowing through cash like it's 5 
minutes till the rapture to whom music was a secondary concern.  We loved 
our drugs, our freaky selves, and the music, PERIOD.  It's not that we 
couldn't succeed in that scene, it's that it's a sad display built around 
money, pussy, fashion and trends.  The clubs embodied that.  So we went 
underground and ducked the whole thing.  Fuck the law, fuck the club 
scene, fuck it all, we were plugged in and we weren't begging for people 
to show up.  Somehow that took care of itself.  We did so well, that 
places like Sound Factory and 1015 started looking to US for what to do 
next... and they couldn't, because those places couldn't compete with the 
freedom, the autonomy, the underground economy and ultimately dealing with 
a crowd that didn't seem too intersted in overpriced drinks... as if we'd 
figured out another way to have a good time.  Well actually, they delved 
into that and got busted 7 ways from sunday.  And they actually got to a 
point where they started calling the cops on UGs.  Oooops.  And then they 
tried to work with us.  Gosh, seems it's easy to forgive anything when 
there's a dollar to be made.

-&e->Maybe I go to the wrong parties sometimes but undergrounds in sketchy 
-&e->hoods are just liabilities for temporary fun. Not to mention I am old 
-&e->enough to get into a club so a party that I would have went to as a 
-&e->teen is not that appealing. In this day and age not knowing where the 
-&e->party is going to be until you get a map or wait until a few hours 
-&e->before the info is released is not that big of a deal and hardly 
-&e->surprising. I spend lots of money when I go out so I try and choose 
-&e->where I go wisely and getting laid after working my balls off all 
-&e->week matters to me?

Sometimes I've got money, and sometimes I don't, but I never like feeling 
like I'm in a place where that's all that matters.

Isaac, are you sure you're not the guy who used to throw parties at a 
space called the crackhouse, more than once even?  I'll spare the list the 
details, but I remember those days well.  In any case, shaky ground to 
stand on when talking about UGs in sketchy hoods.

;)
andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Public Service Annoucement

have you listened to fabric 22 by adam beyer? techno's changed. there's 
so many house references and micro house changes in there and alot of 
progressive elements..  in my mind that mix is more techno than it was 
ever, because i think it has tracks that are number one, by all techno 
artists and number, two could quite possibly be an evolution of techno 
rather than a regression. that shit is fresh. and that's what techno is 
all about, being fresh.

as much as i love being beaten up by the speakers when a tough and dirty 
techno track is being played by a seminal midwest hero like say, jeff 
mills, i also enjoy the new shit just as much. i love where techno is 
going and love that it has changed so much in the last 5 years. even 
jeff mills'  stuff with the all the soundtrack work he has done for 
silent films is incredible and different.

no beef. i used to only like the hard stuff and thought all the new 
stuff was shite.. but people are really stirring up the pot these days 
-it's not the same old stuff, and that's exciting. . i don't know what 
sort of new techno track will be coming along next.

you should be happy.. techno still rules and it is the one of the most 
advanced genres today along side skwee, dubstep, experimental, and 
whatever you want to call idm.

peace love techno. `;)

sean.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!




On Wed, Jul 09, 2008 at 02:39:14PM -0700, electrofunk138@hotmail.com wrote:
> Electro-house like any other genre has crap in it. I have to chuckle at folks who always single out some particular genre to say how awful it is when it becomes super popular, considering every genre has had it's moment in the sun, and every genre has had it's share of crap tunes being churned out. 

I think there's this tendency to notice the increase in crap over the increase
in great tracks, simply because the great tracks are always in the minority.

Arguably, there are only going to be about the same number of great tracks
that really break new ground.  This means that as any genre gets even a bit
more popular, the % of tracks worth listening to goes down.  It's always
easier to suck than excel.

Something I consider an ironic validation that techno is blowing up this
year, is that I've actually been starting to hear some of the most mind
numbing, boring ass commercial sounding techno ever this year.  I just
don't want to hear it at a party. :)

But none of that really matters.  It isn't just that beatport makes it easy,
it's the flip side of what was brought up earlier this year.  Now that big
labels no longer have a stranglehold, ANYONE can churn out crap to try and
make money(or even make art that just doesn't work for anyone else), while
the artists who really work their craft still do what they have to do to get
their work out there.  As so many have said, you end up relying on references
from other people to help narrow the field, and other means.  Some labels
are consistently better, some artists continue to break new ground, etc.

And it doesn't matter how many crap tracks there are if the worthwhile ones
still come out at the same rate.  No matter how much crap is there, parties
still run the same length of time, and sets are still the same length. You
get just as much time for a gig today as you did last year or 5 years ago.
The hard part is, and always has been, in figuring out better ways to skip
the crap without missing the jewels.  But even in the height of vinyl, there
were tons of releases a week once you got on the lists of enough labels.
Most of them just sucked.  Kind of like now. :)


-R.




> As with any genre, it's which tracks you pick and choose to spin...and seeing as how so many of the local breaks kids are now firmly wedged up the arse of electro-house, it's no big shock to me you hear the same shit out every single fucking time you go out. Those kids tend to cane to death the "top 10" tracks of the month or week or whatever. Now rather than doing it with breaks, they are just doing it with electro-house. Sad really seeing as how there's actually a ton of stuff in that genre that rocks pretty hard and it seems like me and fLOORCRAFT and some of the Bassyx kids are the only people really tapping into the better sounding shit right now....

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

--

Before 1971, the introduction of $1 new debt used to increase the GDP
by as much as $3 or more. Since 1971, this ratio started its
precipitous decline that has continued to this day without
interruption. It went negative in 2006, forecasting the financial
crisis that broke a year later. The reason for the decline is that
irredeemable debt causes capital destruction. It adds nothing to the
per capita quota of capital invested in aid of production. Indeed, it
may take away from it. As it displaces real capital, which represents
the deployment of more and better tools, productivity declines. The
laws of physics, unlike human beings, cannot be conned. Irredeemable
debt may only create make-belief capital.

- Professor Antal E. Fekete

Source:  The August Review - The Twilight of Irredeemable Debt
http://www.augustreview.com/news_commentary/global_banking/the_twilight_of_irredeemable_debt_2008050890/

On Jul 10, 2008, at 5:03 AM, <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:


Amen...I don't think the sucky to awesome track ratio has changed much with the advent of digital music, so much as, the supply has increased so much that the sheer volume of both is higher. 

I always had the same experiences digging in vinyl shops as I do online. For every 50 tracks I listen to, I *might* buy one. But those other 49 tracks are gonna be scooped by my friends, or some DJ I like, so, it's all relative. One man's grass fed, kobe beef porterhouse is another man's ground chuck, ya know?

Date: Thu, 10 Jul 2008 03:54:27 -0700
From: rayw@rayw.net
To: electrofunk138@hotmail.com
CC: dangrsmind@yahoo.com; red_stickman@yahoo.com; sarilion@sarilion.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Your chance to hear Pinkko trainwreck!




On Wed, Jul 09, 2008 at 02:39:14PM -0700, electrofunk138@hotmail.com wrote:
Electro-house like any other genre has crap in it. I have to chuckle at folks who always single out some particular genre to say how awful it is when it becomes super popular, considering every genre has had it's moment in the sun, and every genre has had it's share of crap tunes being churned out. 

I think there's this tendency to notice the increase in crap over the increase
in great tracks, simply because the great tracks are always in the minority.

Arguably, there are only going to be about the same number of great tracks
that really break new ground.  This means that as any genre gets even a bit
more popular, the % of tracks worth listening to goes down.  It's always
easier to suck than excel.

Something I consider an ironic validation that techno is blowing up this
year, is that I've actually been starting to hear some of the most mind
numbing, boring ass commercial sounding techno ever this year.  I just
don't want to hear it at a party. :)

But none of that really matters.  It isn't just that beatport makes it easy,
it's the flip side of what was brought up earlier this year.  Now that big
labels no longer have a stranglehold, ANYONE can churn out crap to try and
make money(or even make art that just doesn't work for anyone else), while
the artists who really work their craft still do what they have to do to get
their work out there.  As so many have said, you end up relying on references
from other people to help narrow the field, and other means.  Some labels
are consistently better, some artists continue to break new ground, etc.

And it doesn't matter how many crap tracks there are if the worthwhile ones
still come out at the same rate.  No matter how much crap is there, parties
still run the same length of time, and sets are still the same length. You
get just as much time for a gig today as you did last year or 5 years ago.
The hard part is, and always has been, in figuring out better ways to skip
the crap without missing the jewels.  But even in the height of vinyl, there
were tons of releases a week once you got on the lists of enough labels.
Most of them just sucked.  Kind of like now. :)


-R.




As with any genre, it's which tracks you pick and choose to spin...and seeing as how so many of the local breaks kids are now firmly wedged up the arse of electro-house, it's no big shock to me you hear the same shit out every single fucking time you go out. Those kids tend to cane to death the "top 10" tracks of the month or week or whatever. Now rather than doing it with breaks, they are just doing it with electro-house. Sad really seeing as how there's actually a ton of stuff in that genre that rocks pretty hard and it seems like me and fLOORCRAFT and some of the Bassyx kids are the only people really tapping into the better sounding shit right now....




----------------------------------------

At 05:35 PM 7/8/2008, George Cochrane wrote:
----- Original Message ----

From: AndyW 

p.s. Yes, I know good taste is relative, but every time I go out lately I

that sounds like Justice.  If you have ADD, go get treatment and/or suck
it up, flush your Ritalin down the shitter and get over the fact that it's
just another word for being easily bored and let us have hyponotic dance
music back on the dancefloor where it fucking belongs.

Amen, that sound got boring pretty quickly, it just doesn't have any dynamics, grates on the ear.  I always feel like I need to driving a camaro on poppers when I hear that stuff.  Also, I've heard you rail on "electro house" here and there, so you'll probably be happy to note that the genre has gone from something I found cool and dynamic to stinking on ice in the span of 6 months, and almost every track I buy now is classified as techno, or maybe tech house.

Electro House = Today's Big Beat, minus the star power.

The cycle begins again, lol,
-G

On Wed, 9 Jul 2008, sean ocean wrote:
-&e->have you listened to fabric 22 by adam beyer? techno's changed. 
-&e->there's so many house references and micro house changes in there and 
-&e->alot of progressive elements..  in my mind that mix is more techno 
-&e->than it was ever, because i think it has tracks that are number one, 
-&e->by all techno artists and number, two could quite possibly be an 
-&e->evolution of techno rather than a regression. that shit is fresh. and 
-&e->that's what techno is all about, being fresh.

Sean,

A) I love you, I love your enthusiasm, and I love that you've ran with the 
torch while I stayed home and wrote grumpy emails.  The thing gets heavy 
after a while and while I still go out I'm not the OUT EVERY NIGHT SOLID 
MOFO I used to be.  As much shit as I give everybody, I'm thankful for 
people like you and GregB... but as long as I have an email account and an 
audience and you all don't do my bidding precisely, I might as well 
complain a bit.  ;)

B) I promise not to get offended that you try to update me on the current 
state of techno by bringing up a mix that's 3 years old.

C) For me, that mix fails as a listening cd, it has iffy continuity, and 
wouldn't do it for me on the dancefloor either.  It's "martini techno", 
and that last track on there makes me want to scratch my eyes out.  I fail 
to consider it coincedence that AB decides to include the two genres that 
were blowing up at the time in Europe (microhouse/minimal and progressive) 
as the two influences he "brings to the techno table" on a mix cd series 
that could have opened him to an audience well beyond those who know his 
techno work.  The Fabric series has produced some great mixes, but that's 
not one of them IMHO (Akufen's set minus the Senor Coconut track is a 
great cd to work to, and I really like the recent Robert Hood one as 
well).

D) On the "Techno's changed" thing... plenty of records came out in the 
late 90s from San Jose/SF that had that sorta proggy/housey vibe mixed 
with techno sound design and flow.  My buddy Lucas Roddenbush was part of 
the SJ techno cabal, and he was one of the more noted pioneers of the 
Tech-house movement (along with Alexi Delano, John Selway, etc... all of 
whom he worked with, I've met, etc).  The minimal/microhousey elements 
have been around a while too; Basic Channel/Chain Reaction, and a TON of 
the early detroit artists drew the template for that as early as 93 or so 
as a reaction to the hard rave cheese that techno was becoming.  A few 
years later we also saw SF as one of the epicenters of the glitch 
movement, which gave birth to the minimal/micro stuff, especially the use 
of sinewy sine-wave subs and using extremely short bits of sampled audio 
to suggest sounds rather than be too literal, and packing on the effects 
to fill the gap.  Do the later iterations of it bring something to the 
table?  Of course they do, I love having Akufen, Villalobos, Timeblind, 
JKC, Deadbeat, Monolake, Pole and a lot of that stuff around... but I also 
don't play it out cause it's more background music and I'm just too much 
of a rave bitch wannabe superstar has-been to play background music (and 
if I do I have way more proper ambient, which makes people lay down make 
out and that's more fun to watch).

I've actually produced and even released some minimal/glitch (Open Mind 
Insert Foot on this compilation 
http://doboxrecordings.com/db/index.php/releases/dbdf006/ comes to mind).  
I've also helped other minimal/glitch freaks get their Max/MSP & Reaktor 
patches working, etc.  It's not that I hate the genre wholesale, just 
don't call it techno without a hyphen or qualifier, and don't call it 
dance music unless you could foreseably break a sweat or move both feet 
and arms to it (the "minimal zombie dance" of one hand sort of doing 
non-descript stuff, other holding a beer while sorta wobbling and 
shuffling feet does not qualify).  It's as related to techno as it is to 
Eno style ambient or Steve Reich or mellower Kraftwerk or Amber-era 
Autechre (all of which are considered *ambient*), yet it seems to have 
hijacked the "techno" name outright.

And finally a moment to discuss Skweee.  I've heard some of it.  The good 
stuff sounds like raw weird electro or techno and is actually quite fun.  
The bad stuff never should have been put out, it's SHOCKINGLY 
"my_first_track.rns" bad.  Don't think it warrants a whole new genre name 
though.  I think terms like Skweee (quirky lo-fi techno/electro with some 
r&b/pop ideas) and Schranz (which is EXACTLY like early UR or Axis and 
it's legion of imitators at their most ass reamingly hardest + maybe some 
cheesy influence from um, gabber) are more marketing than anything else... 
they're not reflective of a sound as much as a scene and a desire to 
differentiate by people who know more about marketing than the history of 
music.

Oh, and all this talk about Schranz made me dig up an old bookmark for the 
crappiest thing ever, but like most things, you can go so bad it becomes 
more awesome than awesome.  And this so qualifies.

http://youtube.com/watch?v=rZBA0SKmQy8

Please Drive Through,
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

this usually goes up on tribe as an event listing and blog, i put it on fac=
ebook and groundscore for the first time, and i have an email list through =
addictech. and now, it's on sfraves.

i just asked the
best question in the world for prompting psychotic giggles.... are they
bringing out the blue or the purple turbos? but that is really for part
3 and this is only part 2. hard as it is not to fast forward i'm going
to take this weekend one night at a time, or i might embarrass myself.
again.
=A0
FRIDAY
one of the great
things about deciding to go big? going big. start the night off early
in the upper haight enjoying the fabulous world of art and fashion with
the traditional friday evening art opening. at pandora's trunk. 544
haight st. @ fillmore. and then.....
=A0
=A0
-TRBL
Anu 6th @ Market
10pm-2am free
=A0
continue the
pre-party with the fringe crew at their monthly TRBL. posse up with the
crew and catch some sweet beats courtesy of TRBL djs Tim Dietz and
absurge and their guests Mycho Cocoa and AudioVoid. then....
=A0
=A0
-hobo tea
1015 Folsom
10pm-? $20
=A0
i hate parties
without names so i made one up. not quite sure where to start with this
one. they're keeping 1015 intimate, 2 rooms and the line-up, from
beginning to end is not to be missed. they're making the front room a
chill lounge. they're specially tunin the sound in the main room for
maximum bass deliverance.=A0 it'll rival that night my
friends dragged me kicking and screaming to 1015 at, like, 10:15 (who
goes there before 12?) and having one of those aurally pristine nights
that are really really hard to end. anyways, here's the line-up. you'll
understand what i mean...
=A0
TIPPER
OOAH
ORGASMITRON
BEATS ANTIQUE
EPROM
HEYOKA


and then..... sunrise somewhere beautiful.=20



peace love and beats- layla
=A0

----- Original Message ----
From: Layla Lewis <layla6942@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, July 11, 2008 3:38:25 PM
Subject: [sfraves] this is how i do

this usually goes up on tribe as an event listing and blog, i put it on facebook and groundscore for the first time, and i have an email list through addictech. and now, it's on sfraves.

i just asked the
best question in the world for prompting psychotic giggles.... are they
bringing out the blue or the purple turbos? but that is really for part
3 and this is only part 2. hard as it is not to fast forward i'm going
to take this weekend one night at a time, or i might embarrass myself.
again.
 
FRIDAY
one of the great
things about deciding to go big? going big. start the night off early
in the upper haight enjoying the fabulous world of art and fashion with
the traditional friday evening art opening. at pandora's trunk. 544
haight st. @ fillmore. and then.....
 
 
-TRBL
Anu 6th @ Market
10pm-2am free
 
continue the
pre-party with the fringe crew at their monthly TRBL. posse up with the
crew and catch some sweet beats courtesy of TRBL djs Tim Dietz and
absurge and their guests Mycho Cocoa and AudioVoid. then....
 
 
-hobo tea
1015 Folsom
10pm-? $20
 
i hate parties
without names so i made one up. not quite sure where to start with this
one. they're keeping 1015 intimate, 2 rooms and the line-up, from
beginning to end is not to be missed. they're making the front room a
chill lounge. they're specially tunin the sound in the main room for
maximum bass deliverance.  it'll rival that night my
friends dragged me kicking and screaming to 1015 at, like, 10:15 (who
goes there before 12?) and having one of those aurally pristine nights
that are really really hard to end. anyways, here's the line-up. you'll
understand what i mean...
 
TIPPER
OOAH
ORGASMITRON
BEATS ANTIQUE
EPROM
HEYOKA


and then..... sunrise somewhere beautiful. 



peace love and beats- layla

Might I ask why you don't do tech stuff?  Do you have an interest in it?  Would you do it if you were qualified?  Do you feel like you could learn if you put your mind to it?

You seem like a smart guy, Marco.  The tech industry is *BOOMING* right now, despite the poor economy.  If you know linux, you have people sitting at your doorstep waiting for you to get home to offer you a job.

If you are interested and motivated, I can give you direction on what to study, and where to study.

Take a look at www.vtc.com and see if you like it.  Watch a couple chapters on Win2k3 or Active Directory, or Linux (I'd recommend watching the Red Hat Certified Technician training class to start).

Best of luck, prayers with you.

-Phillip

hnical experience. What little I do have I'd even need refresher work on as=

ort.=20

My problem(s) with learning the whole tech thing are these:=20

1. I need to stay at *LEAST* at my current pay rate. If I get into an entry=
 level tech position=2C I backpedal on payrate by a minimum of about $5-$6 =
an hour. Not acceptable. In fact=2C I almost need that much MORE than I cur=
rently pull down in order to get back on track financially...unless of cour=
se I could luck upon a nice loan to pay off my debt. Sadly my credit rating=
 won't allow for that and I don't know a soul willing (or able) to co-sign =
one for me.=20

2. To get certed for ANYTHING would cost me money I don't have=2C so while =
I could potentially sit at home and do nothing but study shit=2C I wouldn't=
 have any certs or be able to put it on a resume as experience.

3. I need almost every free minute I have to job search=2C and then once I =
find one I need to sink all my time and energy into it so I can get my ass =
back out of the hole I am currently residing in.

Could I learn tech shit? Hell yea=2C with the exception of coding=2C I find=
 most of it fairly easy to understand=2C especially if I have seen it done =
once or twice. Do I have an interest in it? Of course...in this day and age=
 it's almost required=2C isn't it? Would I do it if I was qualified? Of cou=
rse - it would obviously mean way more money. Again=2C refer to aforementio=
ned points as to why I haven't already gone that route.=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: SMall request ...

My company is hiring CSRs and managers.  Unfortunately, our warehouse  
and call center are in Texas. The San Francisco office is mainly  
engineers and merchandisers.  But if you have friends or family in the  
Dallas area and are considering relocating...

... I'm assuming not though.  After all, who would want to goto Texas,  
once you've seen California?

City College is $20 per credit.  I'm working towards my CCNA there  
myself.  It's a good, well-equipped, program.  And they have both  
night and saturday classes so it won't interfere with your work  
schedule.  Considering how much of a pay bump that is, it may be worth  
breaking down and putting it on a card.  The new program even puts all  
the course materials online, so there's no added cost for the  
textbooks. Plus, there's financial aid.  Yes, even City College is  
eligible for it.  I don't know the details because I never bothered.   
But it's all over their website.  Fall semester is in registration now.

I don't even HAVE the thing yet, and I've had a couple of people  
approach me about my impending shift from QA to IT.  That IPv6  
transition is looming on the horizon getting ready to drop on  
everyone's heads, after all.

If you don't want to put the classes on a card and run up more debt,  
and can't afford $120 per semester, you might consider picking up a  
second job at a Starbucks.  I worked at one for a while during the  
hardcore tech doldrums.  And it's not a bad deal at all.

If you work more than 20 hours a week, you qualify for full benefits.   
So that takes care of your health coverage right there; and for your  
other job you can pick one with no bennies and a few more bucks per  
hour.  You get some miscellaneous other perks, including a fantastic  
discount at 24-Hour Fitness.  Those free pounds of coffee every week  
make for great low-cost gifts.  (Who doesn't like coffee, after all?)   
All the free coffee you can drink yourself.  If you work closings and  
have a cool manager, you can eat well on the leftovers.  And here's  
the kicker:  once you've been there for a while, they do TUITION  
REIMBURSEMENT.

And no, that's not just tuition reimbursement for food service related  
certs.  They'll cover tech certs and general degree programs as well.

Busting ass and working two jobs is never fun; especially when you're  
going to school too.  But get a couple of tech certifications under  
your belt, and your worries will be over.  I think that's the biggest  
mistake I ever made after the dotcoms collapsed... not getting my ass  
own right back into school ASAP.


cya,
john
