Subject: [sfraves] BSP: 7/30/08 - Cable Wednesdays vs. DeTension w/ DJ Icon and more!


Every 5th Wednesday=2C Cable Wednesdays and the DeTension party join forces=
 to bring you an amazing night of futuristic house=2C breaks=2C and electro=
.
The first one that we did together a couple of months was ridonkulous!  So.=
..we figured we'd bring back DJ Icon again to repeat that vibe.   :)

Shine
1337 Mission (btwn 9th & 10th)=2C S.F.=2C CA=2C 94103.

9pm - 2am
21+

No cover!!!!!!!!!!
2-4-1 Smirnoff cocktails all night.

Free photobooth from FLICKR. (Shine's FLICKR is adult rated=2C so feel free=
 to go crazy!)

Special guest:=20

DJ Icon=20

Without doubt=2C DJ ICON has become a permanent fixture in the U.S. dance m=
usic industry. With a career spanning more than a decade=2C she has captiva=
ted audiences the world over with her energetic performances=2C magnetic st=
age presence=2C and massive dancefloor-moving blend of Nu-School Breaks=2C =
Tech Funk and Electro House=3B and has become recognized as one of the lead=
ing ladies of Breakbeat.

Starting in 1996=2C ICON diligently rose through the ranks of the San Franc=
isco underground at a time when female DJs and promoters were few. In just =
a few years=2C her skills had already landed her numerous residencies in Sa=
n Francisco and bookings throughout the United States and far beyond. In th=
e time since=2C ICON has also gained success in radio and television in add=
ition to rocking dancefloors worldwide. She is ranked in Shejay's "Top 100 =
Female DJs" and was recently voted as one of San Francisco's top ten DJs in=
 the 2008 Nitevibe "Top 10 DJ Dreamteam" Poll.

Over the last decade=2C ICON has performed in countless cities throughout N=
orth America and Europe and has held residencies at world famous clubs such=
 as Limelight in New York City as well as San Francisco's 1015 Folsom=2C Th=
e End-Up and Temple. She has shared the stage with major dance music player=
s such as The Chemical Brothers=2C Crystal Method=2C Paul Oakenfold=2C Sand=
ra Collins=2C Adam Freeland=2C Deekline=2C Elite Force=2C Dylan Rhymes=2C U=
berzone=2C General Midi=2C DJ Icey=2C Baby Anne and many more.

In addition to her reputation on the dancefloor=2C ICON has dominated the r=
adio waves with residencies and guest spots on a plethora of popular long-r=
unning dance music programs such as Thump Funk on XM Satellite Radio and Bo=
ombox Mix Sessions on Sirius=3B Solid State on K-ROCK in NYC=3B IBreaks in =
the UK=3B and a myriad of shows in the San Francisco Bay Area=2C including =
House Nation on Wild 94.9 FM=2C Subsonic on Live 105=2C Zendada on Energy 9=
2.7=2C and Future Breaks on KUSF. She has also made her way onto the small =
screen with two television series on major cable channels. In 2001=2C she w=
as featured as one of twelve up-and-coming American DJs alongside DJ Craze=
=2C Reid Speed=2C Vinroc=2C and Disco D in "Disc Jockey=2C" a 12-part docum=
entary series that aired on Showtime-- and ShoNext--. In 2003=2C she was ca=
st as the DJ on the internationally syndicated MTV-- series "The Wade Robso=
n Project=2C" a dance competition hosted by the self-titled super choreogra=
pher.

As an integral member Sister - the influential female DJ collective from Sa=
n Francisco - ICON has endeavored to create a thriving DJ community and sup=
port network for women in the dance music industry. In 2001=2C ICON helped =
launch the successful New York City chapter of Sister. Returning to San Fra=
ncisco in 2003=2C ICON established one of the last vinyl record stores=2C R=
everb Records=2C with former business partner DJ Mystre. In an era when rec=
ord stores were becoming extinct=2C ICON catapulted the shop to success as =
it became an essential source for Breakbeat followers. Reverb was an import=
ant focus point in San Francisco DJ culture until its doors closed in 2007.

So what's next for DJ ICON? A promising slate of productions and collaborat=
ions are on the way=3B and if the last decade has proven anything=2C 2008 w=
ill continue to bring big things from this exciting and versatile performer=
.

=20
And your DeTension and Cable Wednesdays residents:=20

Ace Tatsu (Bassyx.org)

DJ Ace Tatsu relocated to San Francisco in 1996=2C from Brooklyn=2C NY=2C w=
here he was born and raised. New to the city=2C he started exploring San Fr=
ancisco's famous nightlife=2C discovering new restaurants=2C lounges and da=
nce clubs on a regular basis. Having traveled a good portion of the world e=
arly on in his ventures =2C provided Ace with a grander view of what life h=
ad to offer=2C but there was something magnetically appealing about San Fra=
ncisco that kept him in this city. A place so rich in culture and diversity=
. Soul and creativity oozing from every corner. Intertwined and amplified s=
o richly by its inhabitants through music. In recollection=2C the first tim=
e the sound captivated him=2C Ace was listening to 'Mushroom Jazz' by Mark =
Farina. It was a sound that was soulful=2C deep and took you away on a magi=
cal journey. From that point on=2C music was no longer a sound=2C but a des=
tination. It was the rich soulful feeling that radiated from this music tha=
t eventually translated into a passion=2C leaving Ace wanting to learn more=
 about the process of melding these audible delights together=2C and creati=
ng that same feeling he felt that day for others. Using a pair of turntable=
s his Brother loaned him=2C and a Mixer from Dj Kimani=2C he began his ques=
t into the realm of Deep House Music.

As San Francisco's DJ culture erupted=2C Ace gained extensive exposure to o=
ther mixing styles ranging from Hip Hop and Mash ups to Breaks=2C Progressi=
ve house and Trance and experimenting with all. A huge influence in his ear=
ly stage of music=2C an old friend DJ/Producer Jorge Torres lent a helping =
hand by rendering four crates of his own House records collection. These re=
cords were proven to be a catalyst early on in his musical venture.

In 2005=2C the passion developed into an obsession. At times=2C as though d=
riven by a spiritual force=2C the relentless urge to search for music and c=
reate journeys was unmistakable. The end of 2005 came with his first mix cd=
 release 'Love Groove' a smashing success for fans of deep sexy house music=
. Following 6 Months later was 'Love Accelerated'=2C another deep sexy soul=
ful mix=2C with a dash of international flavor.

2005 was also the year that Ace began to use Serato Scratch live in his ars=
enal=2C upon recommendation from Dj Kimani. Having looked up to his flawles=
s mixing style and genuine success as a dj=2C he knew that if Kimani was us=
ing this system=2C it must be the real deal. When asked about serato=2C Ace=
 replied "Having the ability to have your whole musical arsenal with you at=
 anytime=2C anywhere=2C allows you to work on complete artistry in your per=
formances without giving up the feel of vinyl. This is a new time and age=
=2C and the sound that will evolve from this=2C will take music lovers to n=
ew heights.

When asked about Musical selections that influenced his early style=2C Ace =
showed appreciation for Miguel Migs and the Naked Music label=2C Hedkandi=
=2C and the music played by local favorites such as Julius papp=2C Kaskade=
=2C jay j and Donovan to name a few. Other influences such as little louie =
vega=2C Dj Gregory=2C lawnchair generals=2C late night alumni=2C Jask=2C Ge=
ne Farris and Fish Go Deep played a huge part in molding his mixing charact=
er.

It wasn't long before Ace had various Residencies under his belt in the cit=
y at places like 111 Minna=2C Blupointe=2C Velvet lounge=2C Lucid=2C Circol=
o and many more. Just recently his tunes have hit Nihon=2C an intimate upsc=
ale whiskey/Japanese cuisine lounge in the Heart of SOMA=2C and Straits SF =
as well as Straits Santana row which draws an upscale sexy crowd and is a c=
osmopolitan hotspot on the weekends.

Today Ace's Music evolves as he is incorporating his past-to-present music =
styles and versatile beats. Club owners and promoters find it a pleasure to=
 work with him because of his practical down to earth attitude and work eth=
ic. He is genuinely interested in the success of all parties and individual=
s involved during his performances. These days his sound is becoming more p=
rogressive=2C yet keeping the sexiness that it is known for. 2007 saw the r=
elease of his 'Balance' mixed Cd series..in which this fresh new sound is e=
xhibited. Having his aim set on the World=2C be on a lookout for his musica=
l journeys=2C heading your way! His 'One Love' belief in combination with h=
is always-fresh music style Deep Sexy House illuminates positive vibes amon=
gst his audience and industry's most critical ears. As Ace's Popularity con=
tinues to rapidly gain momentum=2C his reputation for consistency and artis=
try also continues to make its mark throughout the Circuit Scene.


DJ Gunz (Bassyx.org)

His blend of House=2C Electro House=2C and Breaks always rocks the crowd. A=
lways bangin' and always the nicest guy around!
=20
Marc(O) (Otherworld=2C The Midnight Sons)

All you need to know about Marc(O) in a nutshell: he is equal parts dirty f=
uckin' beats & booty shakin' basslines. His watch is permanently set to 4:2=
0. He doesn't wear his sunglasses at night because they wouldn't sit right =
on his corrective frames. He likes a heaping portion of funk with his tech.=
 He also enjoys B33R:30 almost as much as 4:20. Ladies...he makes a wicked =
marinara=2C so he's sort of domesticated=2C but we all still think of him a=
s a wild animal.  Rocks adidas *never* rock FILA. His motto: "If the shit f=
its=2C WEAR IT!"

Justin Johnson (Cable Recordings=2C Barely Legal Records)

DJ/ Producer Justin Johnson has been rocking the dance floors of North Amer=
ica for over 22 years.Justin originally began DJing back in '85 on his high=
 school radio station=2C KSRH (San Rafael=2C CA).In '94=2C he packed his ba=
gs and moved to NYC.He began working at Satellite Records in New York City =
and quickly became a main buyer and the stock manager for all 3 stores (Bos=
ton=2C NYC=2C Atlanta). After years of consistently rocking the North East=
=2C he became known as the "King of Breaks".An appearance at a massive NYC =
festival (5th Element) was so impressive that it even caught the ears of Th=
e New York Times.The summer of 2003 saw him touring around the country on t=
he Area 2 Festival=2C which featured Moby=2C David Bowie=2C Busta Rhymes=2C=
 John Digweed=2C Carl Cox=2C DJ Dan=2C Tiesto=2C and Dieselboy.

Justin's mix of tribal house=2C disco house=2C funky house=2C sleazy house=
=2C and funky break beats has made him a favorite at countless raves=2C clu=
bs=2C and special events.His influences come from all aspects of music=2C a=
nd he always brings the funk with him.His mix tape and CD series has been a=
pplauded for his flawless mixing skills=2C unique record selection=2C and e=
xcellent programming.Justin's production skills only add to his talent arse=
nal.He has received great reviews and sales on tracks like'97's "Laser Blas=
t"=2C '98's "Cranberry Breaks"=2C '99's "Supernatural"(w John Selway)=2C al=
l on Don't Panic Records.Then came the overwhelming success of his own brea=
ks label=2C Barely Legal Records=2C featuring raw break beat tracks like "A=
ll the Ho's" & "Hot Butta" by King-Size USA founder Scotty Marz.
=20
Never satisfied=2C he has started Cable Recordings with fellow former buyer=
/ manager at Satellite and best friend DJ 3PO.The first release on Cable=2C=
 Secret Society's 'Stolen'=2C caught massive worldwide attention from DJ's =
such as Danny Tenaglia=2C Breeder=2C Quivver=2C Hybrid=2C DJ Dan=2C Satoshi=
 Tomiie=2C John Creamer=2C Danny Howells=2C Taylor=2C John Digweed=2C Antho=
ny Pappa=2C & Seb Fontaine=2C just to name a few.'Stolen' was also featured=
 on Taylor's 'Synaestasia' mix CD on Ultra=2C as well as Dave Aude's 'Noctu=
rnal Wonderland' mix CD on Moonshine. Most recently=2C the track was featur=
ed in Showtime's 'Queer As Folk' series.DJ-Sets.com (Germany) picked up the=
 track for European sales and gave it new life once again and saw another l=
icensing to Slam's CD on Fabric=2C as well as being played by Laurent Garni=
er.

His single "Psychological Warfare"=2C as Secret Society=2C features a remix=
 by Stephane K (John Creamer's partner) was signed and released by Ultra Re=
cords' "You" label to massive international appeal as well as licensing to =
Rui Da Silva's "Miami" Travellers series mix CD.As he prepares Cable's next=
 several offerings=2C Justin continues to amaze the crowds with his live sk=
ills and please listeners alike with his new and original efforts.

There are thousands of DJ's across the globe=2C but few can compare to the =
natural talent=2C experience=2C and skills of Justin Johnson.

> DJ Icon=20
>=20
> Without doubt=2C DJ ICON has become a permanent fixture in the U.S. dance=
 music industry. With a career spanning more than a decade=2C she has capti=
vated audiences the world over with her energetic performances=2C magnetic =
stage presence=2C and massive dancefloor-moving blend of Nu-School Breaks=
=2C Tech Funk and Electro House=3B and has become recognized as one of the =
leading ladies of Breakbeat.
>=20
> Starting in 1996=2C ICON diligently rose through the ranks of the San Fra=
ncisco underground at a time when female DJs and promoters were few. In jus=
t a few years=2C her skills had already landed her numerous residencies in =
San Francisco and bookings throughout the United States and far beyond. In =
the time since=2C ICON has also gained success in radio and television in a=
ddition to rocking dancefloors worldwide. She is ranked in Shejay's "Top 10=
0 Female DJs" and was recently voted as one of San Francisco's top ten DJs =
in the 2008 Nitevibe "Top 10 DJ Dreamteam" Poll.
>=20
> Over the last decade=2C ICON has performed in countless cities throughout=
 North America and Europe and has held residencies at world famous clubs su=
ch as Limelight in New York City as well as San Francisco's 1015 Folsom=2C =
The End-Up and Temple. She has shared the stage with major dance music play=
ers such as The Chemical Brothers=2C Crystal Method=2C Paul Oakenfold=2C Sa=
ndra Collins=2C Adam Freeland=2C Deekline=2C Elite Force=2C Dylan Rhymes=2C=
 Uberzone=2C General Midi=2C DJ Icey=2C Baby Anne and many more.
>=20
> In addition to her reputation on the dancefloor=2C ICON has dominated the=
 radio waves with residencies and guest spots on a plethora of popular long=
-running dance music programs such as Thump Funk on XM Satellite Radio and =
Boombox Mix Sessions on Sirius=3B Solid State on K-ROCK in NYC=3B IBreaks i=
n the UK=3B and a myriad of shows in the San Francisco Bay Area=2C includin=
g House Nation on Wild 94.9 FM=2C Subsonic on Live 105=2C Zendada on Energy=
 92.7=2C and Future Breaks on KUSF. She has also made her way onto the smal=
l screen with two television series on major cable channels. In 2001=2C she=
 was featured as one of twelve up-and-coming American DJs alongside DJ Craz=
e=2C Reid Speed=2C Vinroc=2C and Disco D in "Disc Jockey=2C" a 12-part docu=
mentary series that aired on Showtime-- and ShoNext--. In 2003=2C she was c=
ast as the DJ on the internationally syndicated MTV-- series "The Wade Robs=
on Project=2C" a dance competition hosted by the self-titled super choreogr=
apher.
>=20
> As an integral member Sister - the influential female DJ collective from =
San Francisco - ICON has endeavored to create a thriving DJ community and s=
upport network for women in the dance music industry. In 2001=2C ICON helpe=
d launch the successful New York City chapter of Sister. Returning to San F=
rancisco in 2003=2C ICON established one of the last vinyl record stores=2C=
 Reverb Records=2C with former business partner DJ Mystre. In an era when r=
ecord stores were becoming extinct=2C ICON catapulted the shop to success a=
s it became an essential source for Breakbeat followers. Reverb was an impo=
rtant focus point in San Francisco DJ culture until its doors closed in 200=
7.
>=20

> And your DeTension and Cable Wednesdays residents:=20
>=20
> Ace Tatsu (Bassyx.org)
>=20
> DJ Ace Tatsu relocated to San Francisco in 1996=2C from Brooklyn=2C NY=2C=
 where he was born and raised. New to the city=2C he started exploring San =
Francisco's famous nightlife=2C discovering new restaurants=2C lounges and =
dance clubs on a regular basis. Having traveled a good portion of the world=
 early on in his ventures =2C provided Ace with a grander view of what life=
 had to offer=2C but there was something magnetically appealing about San F=
rancisco that kept him in this city. A place so rich in culture and diversi=
ty. Soul and creativity oozing from every corner. Intertwined and amplified=
 so richly by its inhabitants through music. In recollection=2C the first t=
ime the sound captivated him=2C Ace was listening to 'Mushroom Jazz' by Mar=
k Farina. It was a sound that was soulful=2C deep and took you away on a ma=
gical journey. From that point on=2C music was no longer a sound=2C but a d=
estination. It was the rich soulful feeling that radiated from this music t=
hat eventually translated into a passion=2C leaving Ace wanting to learn mo=
re about the process of melding these audible delights together=2C and crea=
ting that same feeling he felt that day for others. Using a pair of turntab=
les his Brother loaned him=2C and a Mixer from Dj Kimani=2C he began his qu=
est into the realm of Deep House Music.
>=20
> As San Francisco's DJ culture erupted=2C Ace gained extensive exposure to=
 other mixing styles ranging from Hip Hop and Mash ups to Breaks=2C Progres=
sive house and Trance and experimenting with all. A huge influence in his e=
arly stage of music=2C an old friend DJ/Producer Jorge Torres lent a helpin=
g hand by rendering four crates of his own House records collection. These =
records were proven to be a catalyst early on in his musical venture.
>=20
> In 2005=2C the passion developed into an obsession. At times=2C as though=
 driven by a spiritual force=2C the relentless urge to search for music and=
 create journeys was unmistakable. The end of 2005 came with his first mix =
cd release 'Love Groove' a smashing success for fans of deep sexy house mus=
ic. Following 6 Months later was 'Love Accelerated'=2C another deep sexy so=
ulful mix=2C with a dash of international flavor.
>=20
> 2005 was also the year that Ace began to use Serato Scratch live in his a=
rsenal=2C upon recommendation from Dj Kimani. Having looked up to his flawl=
ess mixing style and genuine success as a dj=2C he knew that if Kimani was =
using this system=2C it must be the real deal. When asked about serato=2C A=
ce replied "Having the ability to have your whole musical arsenal with you =
at anytime=2C anywhere=2C allows you to work on complete artistry in your p=
erformances without giving up the feel of vinyl. This is a new time and age=
=2C and the sound that will evolve from this=2C will take music lovers to n=
ew heights.
>=20
> When asked about Musical selections that influenced his early style=2C Ac=
e showed appreciation for Miguel Migs and the Naked Music label=2C Hedkandi=
=2C and the music played by local favorites such as Julius papp=2C Kaskade=
=2C jay j and Donovan to name a few. Other influences such as little louie =
vega=2C Dj Gregory=2C lawnchair generals=2C late night alumni=2C Jask=2C Ge=
ne Farris and Fish Go Deep played a huge part in molding his mixing charact=
er.
>=20
> It wasn't long before Ace had various Residencies under his belt in the c=
ity at places like 111 Minna=2C Blupointe=2C Velvet lounge=2C Lucid=2C Circ=
olo and many more. Just recently his tunes have hit Nihon=2C an intimate up=
scale whiskey/Japanese cuisine lounge in the Heart of SOMA=2C and Straits S=
F as well as Straits Santana row which draws an upscale sexy crowd and is a=
 cosmopolitan hotspot on the weekends.
>=20
> Today Ace's Music evolves as he is incorporating his past-to-present musi=
c styles and versatile beats. Club owners and promoters find it a pleasure =
to work with him because of his practical down to earth attitude and work e=
thic. He is genuinely interested in the success of all parties and individu=
als involved during his performances. These days his sound is becoming more=
 progressive=2C yet keeping the sexiness that it is known for. 2007 saw the=
 release of his 'Balance' mixed Cd series..in which this fresh new sound is=
 exhibited. Having his aim set on the World=2C be on a lookout for his musi=
cal journeys=2C heading your way! His 'One Love' belief in combination with=
 his always-fresh music style Deep Sexy House illuminates positive vibes am=
ongst his audience and industry's most critical ears. As Ace's Popularity c=
ontinues to rapidly gain momentum=2C his reputation for consistency and art=
istry also continues to make its mark throughout the Circuit Scene.

> Justin Johnson (Cable Recordings=2C Barely Legal Records)
>=20
> DJ/ Producer Justin Johnson has been rocking the dance floors of North Am=
erica for over 22 years.Justin originally began DJing back in '85 on his hi=
gh school radio station=2C KSRH (San Rafael=2C CA).In '94=2C he packed his =
bags and moved to NYC.He began working at Satellite Records in New York Cit=
y and quickly became a main buyer and the stock manager for all 3 stores (B=
oston=2C NYC=2C Atlanta). After years of consistently rocking the North Eas=
t=2C he became known as the "King of Breaks".An appearance at a massive NYC=
 festival (5th Element) was so impressive that it even caught the ears of T=
he New York Times.The summer of 2003 saw him touring around the country on =
the Area 2 Festival=2C which featured Moby=2C David Bowie=2C Busta Rhymes=
=2C John Digweed=2C Carl Cox=2C DJ Dan=2C Tiesto=2C and Dieselboy.

and he always brings the funk with him.His mix tape and CD series has been =
applauded for his flawless mixing skills=2C unique record selection=2C and =
excellent programming.Justin's production skills only add to his talent ars=
enal.He has received great reviews and sales on tracks like'97's "Laser Bla=
st"=2C '98's "Cranberry Breaks"=2C '99's "Supernatural"(w John Selway)=2C a=
ll on Don't Panic Records.Then came the overwhelming success of his own bre=
aks label=2C Barely Legal Records=2C featuring raw break beat tracks like "=
All the Ho's" & "Hot Butta" by King-Size USA founder Scotty Marz.
> =20

er/ manager at Satellite and best friend DJ 3PO.The first release on Cable=

shi Tomiie=2C John Creamer=2C Danny Howells=2C Taylor=2C John Digweed=2C An=

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Aug.2nd [KONTROL] w/ Triple R (Traum, Kompakt: Cologne)

Saturday, August 2nd, 2008

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Cologne, Germany
in an exclusive appearance:

TRIPLE R   (aka Riley Reinhold)

Traum . Trapez . MBF . Kompakt


Riley Reinhold, best known as Triple R, has been a hugely
influential figure in Germany's dance music culture for nearly
20 years.  Starting off as a DJ at early illegal parties in his
native Cologne, he soon found himself writing for top music
mags (including his own De:Bug) before going on to co-found
the revered labels Traum, Trapez, and MBF.  Between his
years at the Kompakt record shop, developing talent for his
5 labels, residencies at Cologne's best clubs, a radio show,
and organizing monthly parties, it's no wonder he's
practically considered a national treasure.  This month we
are thrilled to share some of the riches with San Francisco
with an extended West Coast debut set.


with special guest:

CHRISTIAN MORA (bang the box)


and [KONTROL] residents:

ALLAND BYALLO  (nightlight music . auralism . leibe*detail)
NIKOLA BAYTALA  (s.w.a.t . robsoul . junior boys own)
CRAIG KUNA  (platform . esdjco)


____________________________________________________


The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K38/K38F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K38/K38B.jpg

Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K38/K38P.jpg

___________________________________________________


TRIPLE R (aka Riley Reinhold)

Riley Reinhold (aka Triple R) is part owner of the Traum Schallplatten
family of labels encompassing Traum, Trapez and MBF. He started DJing in
1984 in Cologne and later on at electronic dance parties in 1989. Together
with Sascha K=F6sch (now Chief Editor of De:BUG) the pair assembled their o=
wn
sound system in 1990, playing at early techno, house and acid parties at
every club and party imaginable (both legal and illegal) throughout Cologne
and beyond.

>From 1991 to 1993 Riley belonged to the early Force Inc DJ team, together
with Ian Pooley, Tonka, T.P. Heckmann (Live), and Alec Empire, playing at
big clubs in Switzerland and Austria. He was resident at the legendary
Elektro club in Berlin 1993 in the company of DJs such as Robert Hood, Dave
Clarke, Kotai. Later he DJed at its successor, the Panasonic club. He was
also resident at Ego in Dusseldorf, with Florian from Kraftwerk a regular i=
n
the crowd.

In 1994 he was sent to London to meet the Aphex Twin and write an article
about the vast emerging breakbeat scene in London together with Sascha
K=F6sch. His record reviews and articles in the biggest german indie mag SP=
EX
and later Frontpage (an icon for techno culture in Berlin) from 1994 to 199=
8
earned him an international reputation as a journalist which later resulted
in the formation of his own magazine De:BUG.

For the last three years, Riley has been resident DJ at the largest techno
club in Cologne, Sensor, playing with guests such as Swayzak, Carl Craig,
Daniel Bell, Thomas Brinkmann, Miss Kittin, Richie Hawtin, Magda, Green
Velvet, Markus Nikolai, Alter Ego, Steve Bug, Luciano and Broker/ Dealer. H=
e
also plays occasionally at Camouflage together with Sascha K=F6sch and has
been offered a residency at Subway in Cologne. More recently, Riley has bee=
n
hosting a new monthly night called MBF CLUB since June 2005.

Riley was involved for seven years at the Kompakt record store but quit in
2004 to concentrate on his labels Traum, Trapez and MBF together with
Jacqueline Klein.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

A recent interview with Triple R in Resident Advisor:
http://www.residentadvisor.net/podcast-episode.aspx?id=3D108

Triple R's website:
http://www.traumschallplatten.de/

Triple R's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/triple%20r

Triple R on MySpace (w/ music samples):
http://www.myspace.com/rileyreinhold


=3D=3D=3D> MUSIC:

Triple R - Resident Advisor Podcast 108
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K38/Triple_R_-_Resident_Advisor_Podcast_108.mp3

Triple R - Traum 100 Radio Mix
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K38/Triple_R_-_Traum_100_Radio_Mix.mp3


=3D=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Triple R - Live in Paris (parts 1 - 3)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DA8eHCHaFwQA
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DP2X_IpyO22k
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Daw-x3eOpot4

___________________________________________________


CHRISTIAN MORA

Christian's story has only begun to be written. After getting his start in
1995, he began to make a name for himself by playing undergound parties,
mantaining residencies, and organizing full-moon parties all across Mexico.
After making the move to San Francisco in 2000, he started working at the
now defunct Nemesis distributor, helping to service dance music stores
across the states as well as his own store Crescent Records in Guadalajara.
By melding house, tech house, techno and electro into his own signature
blend, his good ear and taste for music has allowed him to DJ not only in
Mexico, but Spain, Holland, Japan and the States. For the last couple of
years, Christian as been playing club and underground events as a member of
Bang The Box, alongside fellow San Franciscans Solar, Lance DeSardi, and
Guada. Previous Bang The Box guests have included John Tejada, Dan Curtin,
Jona, Dollz At Play, Alexkid, and Mr. C., with many more on the horizon.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

Christian Mora on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/christianmorag

Bang The Box on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/bangtheboxsf


___________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

From: "Nyc Labrets" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0

	boundary="----=_Part_81386_19317167.1217464115884"

Subject: [sfraves] Propeller-head Linux based question

------=_Part_81386_19317167.1217464115884
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

After upgrading to Vista Ultimate, which is indeed a stable and robust OS,
(unlike the pre-loaded Home Edition, hmmm), I got hit w/a piece of malware
which rendered it so buggy that I switched to running Linux Puppy/Ubuntu off
of a Live CD.

Here's the deal.

I've got about 50+ gigs of files/work that I want to preserve, that I can
see and access while running LP/U and I want to move them to a section of
the hard drive that I won't be installing XPsp3/Linux onto.

Can anyone here please point me in the right direction for a step by step
walk thru of this process?

Let me pre-empt the 'get a mac' acolytes by stating that I plan to get one
in the near future and that I'd go the pure linux route if it weren't for
the extra 15 steps I gotta take everytime I plug a new piece of HW into this
box, m'kay?

Also, I'm not too keen on burning x amount of gigs onto DVDs, in this, or
any other, lifetime.

Thanks!

~Nyc

ntually it will learn how to        outsmart his medications. =0A=93The vir=
us is truly complex and has many tricks up its sleeve,=94 Paul        said.=

 weak spot of HIV,=94 he said. =0APaul and his team have zeroed in on a sec=
tion of a key protein in HIV=92s        structure that does not mutate. =0A=

of calling it the Achilles heel,=94 Paul said. =0AThat Achilles heel is the=
 doctors=92 way in.  They take advantage of it        with something called=

infusing into the human subjects with HIV infection, essentially to=0Amove =
the virus,=94 Paul said. =0ABasically, their idea could=0Abe used to contro=
l the disease for people who already have it and=0Aprevent infection for th=
ose at risk. =0AThe theory has held up in lab and animal testing.  The next=

ple are diagnosed with HIV. =0AThe doctors still need funding to launch hum=
an trials.  In the world of=0AHIV research, that=92s often where things fal=

that after 30 years of work, you find it doesn=92t work,=94 Paul said. =0AB=
ut so far, it is working. =0A=93This is the holy grail of HIV research, to =
develop a preventative        vaccine,=94 Paul said. =0A=93If we can get th=
e viral loads down to a manageable level, that will=0Apreclude the need for=

eople with HIV. =0AThe doctors know people like Ford Stuart are waiting. =

Holy shit. What's next, a cure for cancer?

On Thu, Jul 31, 2008 at 11:31 AM, CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com> wrote:

> I've been trying to hold back on the NRR posts, but I found this one real=
ly
> fascinating:
>
>
> http://www.fox11az.com/news/topstories/stories/NWkmsb20080730_hiv_breakt-=
hrough.1971ecbd.html
>
> Doctors may have found a way to destroy HIVHOUSTON -- There is real hope
> that what's happening in a Houston lab        might lead to a cure for HI=
V.
> "We have found an innovative way to kill the virus by finding this
> small region of HIV that is unchangeable," Dr. Sudhir Paul of the
> University of Texas Medical School at Houston said.
> Dr.
> Paul and Dr. Miguel Escobar aren't talking about just suppressing HIV =96
> they're talking about destroying it permanently by arming the immune
> system with a new weapon lab tests have shown to be effective.
> Ford Stuart has been HIV positive for 15 years. He's on a powerful drug
> cocktail that keeps the disease in check.
> "I'm on four
> different medications. Three of them are brand new, and it's the first
> time that I've ever been non-detectible," Stuart said. "I'm down to
> about =96 just for the HIV =96 about nine pills per day, five in the
> morning and four at night."
> But Stuart knows HIV mutates, and eventually it will learn how to
>  outsmart his medications.
> "The virus is truly complex and has many tricks up its sleeve," Paul
>  said.
> But Dr. Paul thinks he's cracked a code.
> "We've discovered the weak spot of HIV," he said.
> Paul and his team have zeroed in on a section of a key protein in HIV's
>    structure that does not mutate.
> "The virus needs at least one constant region, and that is the essence
> of calling it the Achilles heel," Paul said.
> That Achilles heel is the doctors' way in.  They take advantage of it
>  with something called an abzyme.
> It's naturally produced by people, like lupus patients. When they
> applied that abzyme to the HIV virus, it permanently disarmed it.
> "What we already have in our hand are the abzymes that we could be
> infusing into the human subjects with HIV infection, essentially to
> move the virus," Paul said.
> Basically, their idea could
> be used to control the disease for people who already have it and
> prevent infection for those at risk.
> The theory has held up in lab and animal testing.  The next step is
>  human trials.
> Meanwhile, every day in Houston, three people are diagnosed with HIV.
> The doctors still need funding to launch human trials.  In the world of
> HIV research, that's often where things fall apart.
> "Clinical trials are very expensive," Paul said.
> "That is the worry of the researcher. This is what nightmares are made
> of =96 that after 30 years of work, you find it doesn't work," Paul said.
> But so far, it is working.
> "This is the holy grail of HIV research, to develop a preventative
>  vaccine," Paul said.
> "If we can get the viral loads down to a manageable level, that will
> preclude the need for these conventional drugs," Escobar said.
> Still, even if everything goes well, it's at least five years before the
>      research could help people with HIV.
> The doctors know people like Ford Stuart are waiting.
> "There are so many people struggling with the disease because it
> affects not only your body, but also your psyche, how you perceive
> yourself," he said.
> If nothing else, the research is promising for the tens of millions
>  waiting for a cure.
> peace
>
> chuck
>
>
>

In-Reply-To: <7237bf9f0807301728ib2d1b82odf74de98005d0c4@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0807311302190.26536@atari>
References: <7237bf9f0807301728ib2d1b82odf74de98005d0c4@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: NRR: Re: [sfraves] Propeller-head Linux based question


Use NRR in the header for totally un-rave/club/osby related posts please.

On Thu, 31 Jul 2008, Nyc Labrets wrote:
-&e->After upgrading to Vista Ultimate, which is indeed a stable and 
-&e->robust OS, (unlike the pre-loaded Home Edition, hmmm), I got hit w/a 
-&e->piece of malware which rendered it so buggy that I switched to 
-&e->running Linux Puppy/Ubuntu off of a Live CD.

What malware?  You might still be able to use it, very few windows 
infections result in a unusable o/s with a little prodding.

-&e->Here's the deal.
-&e->
-&e->I've got about 50+ gigs of files/work that I want to preserve, that I can

ROFL, you've got maybe 5 gigs of work, and 45 gigs of porn, warez and 
bittorrent/limewire flotsam (how do you think you got the malware 
buddy!)...

-&e->see and access while running LP/U and I want to move them to a section of
-&e->the hard drive that I won't be installing XPsp3/Linux onto.

If your hard drive is partitioned into multiple partitions or you 
currently have multiple hard disks somewhere, it's easy.  If it's not, 
you'll need an external drive for a few, or take your chances with 
something like http://gparted.sourceforge.net/livecd.php (it's like a 
linux live distro that has tools for changing partition sizes *hopefully* 
without nuking their contents) or partition magic (insert distant laughter 
here) and create a new partition on the drive without removing the 
existing data.  None of this is foolproof, even if the operator isn't a 
fool so be careful:

With GParted you'd shrink your current windows partition by 50+ gb, then 
create a new partition, format it, then copy your files there, and then 
install your new os to your old (original) partition.

But the external disk is the best answer.

-&e->Let me pre-empt the 'get a mac' acolytes by stating that I plan to 
-&e->get one in the near future and that I'd go the pure linux route if it 
-&e->weren't for the extra 15 steps I gotta take everytime I plug a new 
-&e->piece of HW into this box, m'kay?

No operating system is perfect, and even when the os is perfect, things 
can go wrong.

-&e->Also, I'm not too keen on burning x amount of gigs onto DVDs, in this, or
-&e->any other, lifetime.

If this data you claim is so important, is really so important, then treat 
it like it's important.  You have any idea how annoying it is when people 
ask someone who is technically knowledgable to make up for thier laziness 
or lack of foresight?  We're nerds, not magicians.

Go buy an external hard drive, plug it in, get it working, copy your shit 
over, install whatever it is you're going to install, and for the rest of 
your life KEEP YOUR IMPORTANT SHIT IN AT LEAST TWO PLACES and try to run 
your computer more like a server/tool and less like an amusement park 
(malware/virus crap is totally attributed to avoidable user behaviors in 
probably 99% of all cases).

You're lucky you had a "malware" rather than a disk crash.
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

originally set up to keep Command & Control communications functioning, in

>> > you'll need an external drive for a few, or take your chances with
>> > something like http://gparted.sourceforge.net/livecd.php (it's like a
>> > linux live distro that has tools for changing partition sizes
>> *hopefully*
>> > without nuking their contents) or partition magic (insert distant
>> laughter
>> > here) and create a new partition on the drive without removing the
>> > existing data.  None of this is foolproof, even if the operator isn't a
>> > fool so be careful:
>> >
>> > With GParted you'd shrink your current windows partition by 50+ gb, then
>> > create a new partition, format it, then copy your files there, and then
>> > install your new os to your old (original) partition.
>> >
>> > But the external disk is the best answer.
>> >
>> > -&e->Let me pre-empt the 'get a mac' acolytes by stating that I plan to
>> > -&e->get one in the near future and that I'd go the pure linux route if
>> it
>> > -&e->weren't for the extra 15 steps I gotta take everytime I plug a new
>> > -&e->piece of HW into this box, m'kay?
>> >
>> > No operating system is perfect, and even when the os is perfect, things
>> > can go wrong.
>> >
>> > -&e->Also, I'm not too keen on burning x amount of gigs onto DVDs, in
>> this, or
>> > -&e->any other, lifetime.
>> >
>> > If this data you claim is so important, is really so important, then
>> treat
>> > it like it's important.  You have any idea how annoying it is when
>> people
>> > ask someone who is technically knowledgable to make up for thier
>> laziness
>> > or lack of foresight?  We're nerds, not magicians.
>> >
>> > Go buy an external hard drive, plug it in, get it working, copy your
>> shit
>> > over, install whatever it is you're going to install, and for the rest
>> of
>> > your life KEEP YOUR IMPORTANT SHIT IN AT LEAST TWO PLACES and try to run
>> > your computer more like a server/tool and less like an amusement park
>> > (malware/virus crap is totally attributed to avoidable user behaviors in
>> > probably 99% of all cases).
>> >
>> > You're lucky you had a "malware" rather than a disk crash.
>> > andyw
>> >
>> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
>> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

in safe mode and I wouldna bothered if the default wasn't to cut my sound
card out of the picture. I just started doing vid and it was kinda pointless
without audio.

>

but honest, outsourced, Injun, thanks to youporn/redtube there's no longer
any need for me to store any of that locally anymore.

I went back and had another look at the folder where all my shit is and it's
not 50 gigs but 165 gigs.

Oops.

Let me qualify that by saying I'm real new to doing pics/vid and about 95%
of that crap is just that, crap, but it's part of my "learning cliff' and I
want to hang onto it until I feel i'm ready to go to the next level.

>
>
> If your hard drive is partitioned into multiple partitions or you
> currently have multiple hard disks somewhere, it's easy.  If it's not,
> you'll need an external drive for a few, or take your chances with

> here) and create a new partition on the drive without removing the

.
A "short between the headphones" is an operational issue that I'm painfully
aware of.
.

>

> With GParted you'd shrink your current windows partition by 50+ gb, then
> create a new partition, format it, then copy your files there, and then

So sayeth the chorus.

Two words: tight budget.

But yeah, you're right, I did put all my eggs in one basket, thanks for your
time and patience.
.

>
> Go buy an external hard drive, plug it in, get it working, copy your shit
> over, install whatever it is you're going to install, and for the rest of
> your life KEEP YOUR IMPORTANT SHIT IN AT LEAST TWO PLACES and try to run
> your computer more like a server/tool and less like an amusement park

> probably 99% of all cases).
>

.
You have no idea how embarrased I am by this, I'm in my 4th, going on my 5th
decade, next year, of being around 'puters, (i can still hear the screech of
the 'Asteroids' program being played in a straight music cassette player
over the speakers instead of being properly jacked into a Trash-80)  and
I've been way, way more careful around computers then I have ever been with
women, despite the fact that you can't get a box preggers.

At least not yet.

Go figure, because right now, I can't.

Thanks again for taking your time out for me like this, I'm humbled.

~Nyc

>> hit w/a
>> -&e->piece of malware which rendered it so buggy that I switched to
>> -&e->running Linux Puppy/Ubuntu off of a Live CD.
>>
>> What malware?  You might still be able to use it, very few windows
>> infections result in a unusable o/s with a little prodding.
>>
>> -&e->Here's the deal.
>> -&e->
>> -&e->I've got about 50+ gigs of files/work that I want to preserve,  
>> that I can
>>
>> ROFL, you've got maybe 5 gigs of work, and 45 gigs of porn, warez and
>> bittorrent/limewire flotsam (how do you think you got the malware
>> buddy!)...
>>
>> -&e->see and access while running LP/U and I want to move them to a  
>> section of
>> -&e->the hard drive that I won't be installing XPsp3/Linux onto.
>>
>> If your hard drive is partitioned into multiple partitions or you
>> currently have multiple hard disks somewhere, it's easy.  If it's  
>> not,
>> you'll need an external drive for a few, or take your chances with
>> something like http://gparted.sourceforge.net/livecd.php (it's like a
>> linux live distro that has tools for changing partition sizes  
>> *hopefully*
>> without nuking their contents) or partition magic (insert distant  
>> laughter
>> here) and create a new partition on the drive without removing the
>> existing data.  None of this is foolproof, even if the operator  
>> isn't a
>> fool so be careful:
>>
>> With GParted you'd shrink your current windows partition by 50+ gb,  
>> then
>> create a new partition, format it, then copy your files there, and  
>> then
>> install your new os to your old (original) partition.
>>
>> But the external disk is the best answer.
>>
>> -&e->Let me pre-empt the 'get a mac' acolytes by stating that I  
>> plan to
>> -&e->get one in the near future and that I'd go the pure linux  
>> route if it
>> -&e->weren't for the extra 15 steps I gotta take everytime I plug a  
>> new
>> -&e->piece of HW into this box, m'kay?
>>
>> No operating system is perfect, and even when the os is perfect,  
>> things
>> can go wrong.
>>
>> -&e->Also, I'm not too keen on burning x amount of gigs onto DVDs,  
>> in this, or
>> -&e->any other, lifetime.
>>
>> If this data you claim is so important, is really so important,  
>> then treat
>> it like it's important.  You have any idea how annoying it is when  
>> people
>> ask someone who is technically knowledgable to make up for thier  
>> laziness
>> or lack of foresight?  We're nerds, not magicians.
>>
>> Go buy an external hard drive, plug it in, get it working, copy  
>> your shit
>> over, install whatever it is you're going to install, and for the  
>> rest of
>> your life KEEP YOUR IMPORTANT SHIT IN AT LEAST TWO PLACES and try  
>> to run
>> your computer more like a server/tool and less like an amusement park
>> (malware/virus crap is totally attributed to avoidable user  
>> behaviors in
>> probably 99% of all cases).
>>
>> You're lucky you had a "malware" rather than a disk crash.
>> andyw
